y_ev0iGshVPfigi3mlecrA.text: Seating/Wait times: Wait times aren't too bad. There is a lot of seating. The outdoor area is heated to be used in colder weather. We sat out there and were still comfortable.   Food: Amazing!!!  Atmosphere: Laid back. Casual. Lots of fun!

ibacXgv_K4G4G_FfGk4wLg.text: Wifey and I went to Hofbrauhaus for our annual summer visit.  I've been here a handful of times at night but we like the outside seating and it get's so busy at night.   It's not the best experience for us at night here.  So a few years back we came her during the day and it was great.  So when we visit Hofbrauhaus we usually come here early afternoon so we can soak up the sun, enjoy each other, take some cool pictures of us outside, and drinks some liters of beer!       I'm a wheat beer type of guy so I'm in heaven when I am here.  I'll drink their Hefe Weizen any time of the year but it' summer so I had their "Sommer Weizen".  This is just a great summer wheat beer.  Smooth, great color, great summer taste that is very enjoyable.  I wouldn't drink this one all year round if it was offered like the original Hefe Weizen but it's great for the summer.         Our favorite seasonal beer here no doubt is their HB Oktoberfest.  I would drink this one all year round.  We were a little early for this one because it should be available in September.  I hope we can find sometime to come back for that or I'll just have to pick some up at a store no doubt.       My rating is purely for the beer and the day time setting outside.  The bartenders and service was good.  I like the restrooms and they are clean.  Don't get me wrong about the night life here.  I like it here at night but it's too busy for us.  Were getting older we need some more peace and you can find that during the day.  We have never eaten any food here so I can't rate that but it's always tempting.  We just usually throw back a few here, take some cool pics of us drinking a liter of beer, and then we go to dinner somewhere else.         Come here on a warm sunny day, sit outside, get a liter of beer and you will have a great time here at Hofbrauhaus Pittsburgh!

ymOA64Zdf0141fhbYQDY0Q.text: Look, when you're coming to an authentic beer hall, there's going to be a wait.  That's to be expected.  But I've been over Germany, HofBrau Munchen a few times, and other "German" places like Penn Brewery.  Nothing comes as close to the raw bar food feel you'd expect from the sister brewery to the original in Munchen.  Ja, it's touristy, but it's also homey.  Their beers are an obvious must Desserts are old traditional selections Main course items to try that are authentic Bavarian are the:  Weiwurt - peel the skin off and enjoy with light mustard.  It has a light, enjoyable flavor. Knusprige Schweinehaxen - it's a whole pig knuckle meant for two or three people.  (Emphasis on the multiple serving size). Anything with Spatzle - German thick egg noodles served with beef tips or chicken.  I visit with my family every year and every year they never cease to satiate our longing for traditional German food.

vnccEcZEZIBTIBtWKl7qsw.text: I have to be honest: Hofbrauhaus is just not my kind of place. The noise levels alone are enough reason for me to keep my distance. But, a friend really wanted to come here over the weekend to enjoy lots of German food and a side of beer, so I came with an open mind, good company, and an empty stomach.  As I mentioned, the noise level here is not kind to the ears - chatty patrons and (some admittedly fantastic) live performances alike make the volume almost overwhelming. This is not a place to come with a large group or anyone you want to have a real conversation with; you won't be able to hear anyone who's not next to or across from you. I'm admittedly not a fan of the seating here either, as the long tables and long benches ensure that getting up and down if you sit anywhere other than the very end of said tables and benches is not easy.  Once I'd sat down and committed myself to staying in that seat for the duration of the visit, it was time to decide what to order. My group started off with a pretty phenomenal appetizer. It was a sampler with multiple sauces (including some outstanding bier cheese), pretzels, fried prickles, sauerkraut balls, and potato pancakes (with applesauce on the side, of course!). Everything on this sampler was perfect and amazing and delightful. I'm not even usually a fan of sauerkraut, and I enjoyed the fried sauerkraut balls that came with this order.  On to the main courses; I opted for the Munich Market Salad because healthy eating and all that (I know, not exactly the place to go for the healthiest meal - had I mentioned a friend wanted to eat here?). And it was a fairly fancy salad - lettuce, strawberries, cranberries, pecans, pineapple, oranges, feta cheese...a pretty good combination, I'd say. Unfortunately, I also ordered the glazed salmon to top it. That extra salmon cost $4.99 - and as my picture proves, my salad came with the tiniest piece of salmon I've ever seen. I admit, that disappointed me, especially compared to the amount of meat on my friends' various orders. If decimal points were allowed, this surprise would definitely be reflected in my final star rating. But, decimal points are not allowed - and I primarily ordered a good salad, and a good salad was delivered to me. I actually intended to eat half of it and take some home for the next day...yeah, that didn't happen. I enjoyed it all right then and there.  So clearly my experience was up and down, but at the end of the night the downs weren't deal breakers. Like I said, I came with an open mind, and while Hofbrauhaus is not my kind of place, my experience and meal overall was just fine (although I certainly won't be ordering salmon on a salad again here). I admittedly won't become a regular patron any time soon, but I can appreciate why people like it and I won't tell people to avoid it entirely. If I'm asked to return again, I know I would enjoy exploring more of the menu. (And if nothing else, now I know that you can buy growlers at the bar here! Yes please!)

FCo6kbPivgZirimu6eajpQ.text: What do Munich, Las Vegas, and Pittsburgh have in common? They're each home to the authentic Hofbrauhaus German bier garden.  I was pretty excited to hear about the recent opening of the Hofbrauhaus in the ever expanding Southside Works development.  This place is absolutely massive.  I'm not exagerating when I say that they can probably fit 1000 people between the two indoor dining rooms and the two huge patios.  The long wooden benches in the main dining hall are simply designed for mass, communal consumption of beer.  And really, that's what you want to do here.  Hofbrau beer is served in half liter and full liter glass steins, and it is good.  My favorite is the hefewiesen (wheat beer).  It's one of the best hefeweisens I've ever had.  I also tried the seasonal Maibock on my most recent visit.  It had nice body, but at over 7% alcohol by volume, you're not going to finish too many liters of this before you hit the floor.  The Dunkel (literally, dark beer) was also good.  I don't know if they serve it in the main dining hall, but I'm hoping that they serve beer in the 2 liter glass "boots" that they sell in the gift shop.  Back in the day, when I used to live in Madison, WI, there was a German beer hall called the Essen Haus that used to serve beer in these two liter beauties.  There was a game we played with the boot where everyone at the table would take a drink and then pass it to the next person.  If you passed it on, and the next person finished the boot, you had to buy the next boot.  From what I can recall, it was a good time...  As for the food, well, it's German...  If you like wienerschnitzel, bratwurst, and sauerbraten, then you'll be in heaven.  Personally, I find German food heavy and bland, but that's just me.  The pretzels and beer cheese were a great appetizer.  Perfect beer food.  One of my dining companions ordered the "Hot Brown" (Turkey and swiss cheese over a potato pancake, covered in beer cheese and, oh, yeah, bacon).  It was really good, but dense.  In summary, go here with a large group of beer lovers and drink yourself silly on good (reasonably priced - $7/liter) German beer.  Fire down a few pretzels to soak up the alcohol.  Das ist gut.

aEa8ixs61xFrAJ6H8B9c9g.text: It's Like Epcot Center in Pittsburgh, but with Better Food  Yes, this is actually a German beer house here in Pittsburgh at the South Side Works.    The Brau Haus and the neighboring Cheesecake Factory compete for the title of gaudiest architectural monstrosity on the South Side.  It looks like a little beer house plunked down next to the Mon.  When you arrive, you have two choices:  The quiet (read:normal) dining room, and the big beer hall.  We opted for the latter, and were glad we did.  In the big room, your sat next to strangers at big, heavy eight-seater tables.  On one side of the hall, performers in leiderhosen (yes, leiderhosen) play accordions and sing German drinking songs for your enjoyment.  Every so often, the performers call a toast, and everyone in the hall raises a glass and half-sings some German toast song.  It was actually pretty cool, and not that different from Oktoberfest in Munich (or what I remember of it anyway.)  My partner and I split a combination plate ($30), which was more food than either of us could even think of finishing.  It consisted of 2 pork chops, 3 sausages, 3 pork cutlets, mashed potatoes and two kinds of sauerkraut.  The combination plate was a good way to sample some exotic fare without really committing to anything.  We only wished it came with less sauerkraut and more green leafy veggies.  We didn't even come close to finishing the dish, but I still left feeling ten pounds heavier.  There's a reason Germans are so um.... zaftig.  Other (non adventurous) customers near us ordered salads and burgers.  They looked pretty good too, actually.  So you can bring unadventurous/picky eater members of your family to the brau house without fear.    Good luck spelling this place in Web searches.  (Key Words: Brau Haus Hoff BrauHaus)

tSsqPTDh4E1NxXdp0XnwLg.text: When family or friends come to visit, they often want to come here because of the fun atmosphere and delicious beer. I'm not a huge beer drinker, but I could easily drink a liter of Heffeweisen here. With its smooth finish and perfect hint of banana, I would highly recommend it.  I love starting with the beer cheese and pretzels. I could eat their beer cheese on a absolutely anything. The pretzels are perfectly salty, and the beer cheese is creamy with just a hint of tartness. The fried pickles are also a delicious starter.  For entrees, I love the bauern sandwich. It comes on a pretzel bun and is smothered with beer cheese. The beer cheese chicken is also delectable, as are the schnitzel options and buttered spaetzle.  If you are looking for a loud ambience, sit in the main dining room and experience live music as well as people dancing on the tables. If you are looking for something a bit low key, sit outside in the heated patio area. When the weather is nice, it's fun to experience the beer garden where you seat yourself and enjoy the beautiful view of the river.  If you still have room left, the apple strudel is really delicious. If you're looking for a fun place to try with friends, you won't be disappointed.

1UT3s-wOnEGt1UW6IBQwsQ.text: Got here late and had a 32 oz of the dunkel. Good German style beer. The bartenders only let you buy one at a time which is lame. The live band plays Ein Prosit about every 25 minutes but stupidly ends it with the Australian cheer.  We stood on the benches of the tables, had soft pretzels with beer cheese which is really good though not traditional. This place is a sad imitation of the real thing.   Tourist trap.

1laJvC2D9pPTNktnZUBZLA.text: I enjoyed our experience at Hofbrauhaus.  We went on a Sunday afternoon around 3:30 so the cavernous restaurant seemed very empty.  We were quickly greeted and our request for a table inside but with a view of the river was accommodated with a smile.    We started with the "Works" sampler.  Because it was slow in the restaurant, the food came out much more quickly than we had expected it to.  It was tasty and quite a bit of food.  However, it cost more than either of our entrees did.  The pretzels were the standard soft pretzel.  The bier cheese, however, was fantastic!  I wish they would have given us more than just the small cup worth.  The plate also included fried pickels (which were pretty standard as well).  What stood out wer ethe sauerkraut balls (served with honey mustard).  They were unique, crisp and tasty.  The combo was rounded out with potato pancakes served with applesauce.  While I enjoyed the potato pancakes, I expected better from a German restaurant.  Main entrees were the Jagerscnitzel and Kasespatzle.  The Jagerschnitzel is pork with a wine mushroom/bacon sauce.  The pork was tender and the breading crisp and tasty.  It came with a delectable German potato salad and a fried cabbage that I can't say much more about other than "meh."  The Kasespatzle was, as expected, very heavy (the dish contains swiss cheese, onions nad heavy cream sauce).  It was too much for my taste, but my fiance loved it.    While we were dining, a leiderhosen clad accordian player kept the small crowd entertained with traditional German favorites with the Chicken Dance thrown in for good measure.    Overall, we had an enjoyable and tasty experience.  Hofbrauhaus certainly won't be a regular stop, but we will visit again.

KoApq4JqTvYkcLJwYyz-2Q.text: The is such a great fun place. Great environment, great music, great food. There isn't a bad item on the menu, great view when you're sitting outside. The service is phenomenal and it's very large and spacious.

Yyq1GOUw_epSrV4u9ssLKg.text: Accessible parking.  The restaurant feels sterile, even though the decor is Bavarian.  It's too quiet for a place called Hofbrauhaus.  Nevertheless, the beer is fresh and it was a great place to stop on a hot afternoon in Pittsburgh.

SInz0htnA4fp54ogvUilSA.text: A great place to go with large groups of people. Adequate bar food, decent beer, fun entertainment, attentive service. The history is interesting, but the presence of a gift shop adds to the off-putting feeling of fairly obvious American over-commercialization.

eSSKlRZyD02M8VFQ-zejwg.text: There's not too much mystery as to what the Hofbrauhaus is at this point: huge, rambunctious beer hall with German and Not-German-At-All food offerings.  So I'll just offer a couple of thoughts to optimize your 'Haus experience:   1. Outdoor seating is great on warm days/nights.  So what if the Mon River is often sludge brown?  I still get mad at how criminally undeveloped Pittsburgh's riverfront is.  This is one of precious few spots to actually hang out by the water and I'm a fan.   2. The Weizen is legitimately great.  For beers like this, freshness is everything, so getting bottle versions from Germany definitely lose something on the trip over.  And for whatever reason American microbreweries haven't really mastered this style.  So this is a legit German recipe and it's fresh.  Short of going to Munich it's hard to get better.   3.  Definitely recommend the monthly keg tappings.  Fun time and you get to try out the new offering for free in addition to seeing how they used to do kegs in the olden days.

xE4jzvrFOKYHXn2GdCLFkA.text: Do not go to the bier Garten on a sunny Sunday of a holiday weekend. Service took literally hours and some items never arrived yet showed up on the bill. Go to the bar to order anything if the bier Garten is busy, and plan to be there for a long while. That said, if was lovely to be on the river on a sunny afternoon.

ziLmQeG5lzqTxFAv7f3MkA.text: I threw an engagement party for my best friends in one of the private rooms at the Hofbrauhaus.  Kelley Williams helped to assist in planning the function and was amazingly easy to work with, quick and super professional.  She made sure that on the day-of, everything was exactly what we discussed.  The buffet menu looked and tasted fabulous!  The servers who were assigned to wait on my guests were very gracious, fun and made the evening go very smoothly.  I don't have one negative thing to say about my experience hosting a party here.  Kelley and her staff made it the perfect experience and I would definitely have another party at this restaurant!

k1zT1iDBSZQfu_WUp9dr-A.text: I'm partial to Hofbrau only in the summer....in the winter, it gets too cooped up, and I really can't stand the obnoxiously drunk singing inside.  I'm sure some people love it, but it's just not me.  I've spent a lot of time at this place, and you should definitely go here if you haven't been here, just be prepared for LOUD.   I highly recommend you go in the summer and head straight for the back...the downstairs patio outside is a great way to spend a summer evening.  A year ago I probably would have given them 5 stars, but nothing has changed and it gets stale after a while.  If you haven't been here though,  you should absolutely go...there's a reason there are so many reviews.    As far as food, I echo Rachel's sentiment:  TGIFridays but with German food.  The food doesn't do it for me.  Definitely a drinking spot only.    On to the things I do like...the 1L of wheat beer, and the beer cheese + pretzels.  You should get a liter of beer because, well, you can't get it in many other places.  And yes, it is brewed in haus.

The beer is excellent. I asked for a smaller glass because it seemed like the large one was the size of my head. A regular 12-16oz is good for me.  I ordered the reuben sandwich with fries. It was spectacular. Perfect amount of each item on the sandwich. I would definitely order this again.  I would definitely bring kids here during the week. The weekend is very packed and loud.  Hopefully I will be back again before another few years pass!

ihKFvBsURTOuj0CX4CSeNg.text: This is a regular spot for me. When all else fails, when I can't decide on what to eat, or when I don't want to put thought into dinner, I end up here.  The food is pretty good. I love German food so enjoying this food isn't too surprising. I typically get some type of sausage with sauerkraut while my fiance sticks to schnitzel. I know people complain that the food isn't the "freshest" but it's still really good and one of the few places that I can get a more traditional style German meal.  The REAL reason we all go is the beer. German beer are some of my favorites and being able to get it in giant glasses just sends me to heaven. It also forces me to sit and enjoy the beer and company a bit more instead of quickly drinking a 12-16 oz pour and moving on to the next place.  The atmosphere is also pretty fun and they work really hard on that so I applaud them. I've actually been to the original Hofbrauhaus  (just walked through, way to busy to sit and eat/drink) and they did a good job recreating everything. I also really like listening to the accordion player. Almost everywhere else that has that type of music would be too much but it works there because it wouldn't feel like the Hofbrauhaus without it.  Some of the cons are that it is a family place and I know that this is not their fault but I'm always a bit annoyed that while I'm trying to enjoy a meal and beer with my friends there's a screaming kid in the background. It also kind of weirds me out seeing babies and toddlers and breweries, no matter the time. I'm also not the biggest fan of the bench like seating. I don't mind bench seating or even getting put at a table with strangers, I just don't like that the benches are really close to one another and it makes it really hard to get in and out of them. I never like asking people to get out of their seats so I can go to the restroom or get some fresh air and unless you have an aisle seat you have to do that.  There's very few Hofbrauauses in the US and if you like German food and drinks I recommend it. Also if you're someone who enjoys Germany or German culture you should check it out.

EsjtJ9LJRYlGBU6JM9E5iA.text: Stopped in here for lunch on a Tuesday. the area, even in the middle of the day, seemed to only have pay parking. But HB is just off the main area. You can see some of the large brewing equipment on the outside of the building. Step inside though, and you are transported to Bavaria.  Oompah music, long wooden tables, a large, square shaped bar in the middle of the dining room. Waitresses adorned in dirndls, (traditional Oktoberfest attire), and German style beers in 1/2 or full liter pours. If you are looking for a traditional German experience without leaving the country, you found it.  For about $13, you can get a lunch buffet including 3 different sausages, sauerkraut, cabbage, pork cutlet, mashed potatoes, soup, and salad. Its a killer deal for authentic food, especially with the ambiance. Lots of fun.

DUIruOyvu1lSynFXxFxpqQ.text: I can't believe I haven't reviewed this awesome place, despite two trips over the Summer and Fall. We don't live too close, so the trip over is pretty much the whole reason we don't go monthly. For those who aren't local, the 'Burgh isn't easy to travel north-south in...  Anyhoo, I digress. This place is great! We came here with some German friends, and really pressed them about the authenticity of the food and beer. Beers were delicious, as I expected. Good was delicious - Jagerschnitzel, spaetzle, bratwurst, soft pretzels, potato pancakes, sauerkraut poppers, and all the rest we had were awesome! Our German friends loved the place, and vouched for the quality and authenticity of the food and drink, although they did say it wasn't 100% like home, but it was close.  We'll most definitely be back for more. Bring your appetite - this place serves huge portions, and you'll bring boxes home! Uber it for the safest, most enjoyable experience, too. Danke schoen!!!

WQsyvYr8PTbLMRZpDxgMAA.text: If I'm not certain that I would like a restaurant, I often purchase Groupon certificates to kind of wade into the pool from the shallow end...  I actually had a lot of not too favorable thoughts before I went to Hofbrauhaus.  (The thought of men with skinny legs in lederhosen singing "Oompah" or yodeling kind of scared me...)  However, I was really pleasantly surprised and really enjoyed myself in the beer hall and restaurant.  I also enjoyed the food and atmosphere.  Usually when it comes to "theme" restaurants, I turn my nose up. (Unfairly, I know, but everyone has their own idiosyncrasies.)  This was a theme restaurant, however, that was really infectious with their enthusiasm and zest towards their theme..  My daughter Muff ordered the Bier Cheese Chicken ($15.99) with grilled chicken breasts topped with Bier cheese, peppers and onions.  She decided on the fries instead of the mashed potatoes.  I ordered the Bavarian Jagerschnitzel which was a pork cutlet topped with a Burgundy Wine mushroom sauce, onions and bacon.  For my sides, I got the potato pancakes and fried cabbage.  We didn't go with any appetizers because we knew the entrees were going to be a little on the heavy side. (Once you add bacon and potatoes to almost anything, the heaviness factor goes up.)  I must say that everything was pretty tasty.  Our server was extremely friendly and very helpful in helping us in selecting our menu items.  Overall, it was very pleasant experience.  My daughter even said that she wanted to come back again with more family members.  It's that kind of place where Nana, Pap-Pap, Uncle Julius and Aunt Pam and all of the rest of your family (Especially little ones) can come and find something to eat and feel satisfied.  Good clean fun with decent food, sing-alongs and a nice atmosphere.  What's wrong with that?  Nothing, according to me!

xTXrpVi0KvDKZROU_foeWw.text: Normally, Hofbrauhaus is known amongst college students for its Thursday night beer deals during College Night (9-11 PM). As German food isn't know to be the most vegetarian-friendly, I was apprehensive about what my entree options would be. However, there were more vegetarian options than expected, including multiple appetizers, salads, pasta, and garden burger.  For my appetizer, the pretzel and salads complemented each other well. In particular, the pretzel was warm and soft when served and went well with the accompanying mustard. For the main entree, I got the Kaespatzle, which is a pasta with cream sauce, cheese and onions. This dish was slightly heavy and wasn't as flavorful as I was expecting - the first couple bites were good but then the flavors felt a bit monotonous. Dessert included an Apple Strudel and Chocolate Stout cake, both very scrumptious. Overall, its worth a shot to check out the food here, in addition to the beer.

However, they had a big army of servers working and they didn't appear to be frazzled or desperately busy. We ordered three appetizers and she brought little plates for seven of us, I guess the other two people were just supposed to eat out of the communal serving dishes.   After bringing the main dishes, she disappeared. Never came back to check on us or see if we had everything. When we finished, she didn't take away the dirty dishes. I saw the Black Forest Cake on the menu online, so I knew I wanted that for dessert. She never brought menus back for dessert. After a long time sitting among a table full of dirty dishes, she came over to bring the check. I told her I wanted the cake and a coffee. She walked away without asking anyone else in our party if they wanted dessert or coffee. My DIL said, "I guess the rest of us don't get coffee or dessert." She brought my coffee and about ten minutes later when the coffee was almost cold, the cake. Still didn't ask anyone else if they wanted anything, nor did she remove the dirty dishes. Two people snagged her and asked for coffee, but she still didn't give anyone a menu for dessert.   Everyone in our family believes in tipping 20%, but we left her $20 for lousy service. I wouldn't go back there.

9MbbOUGCW_rgRUiqf9mcxQ.text: The people here were really nice. I think they take some slack for the outfits, but they were still very kind.   Oh, and the beer is great...

72Kib3tesaTDCpuPmZtiyw.text: I know, I know..... This is a chain.    I have been to the hofbrau in Germany.   While everything is based on this restaurant, I prefer the Pittsburgh version. 178owfY7ppltaSVoRKoCMA.text: A beautiful place for college kids on a Thursday night during the their college night happy hour. There is live music in the big hall and everyone stands on their chairs with giant beers in hand. Great time! Also, I could live solely on the pretzels and bier cheese!!!

Rom3HKGaOrz7Vmp4VwHsKg.text: I usually don't go to bigger restaurants but this place was very calm on a Wednesday lunch hour. 0yAlyygKqW1dQjtquwGDHg.text: I love this place, the food is amazing, the beer is outstanding and the atomosphere is awesome too.  One of my favorite spots to eat now.  I can't believe I didn't trying this place sooner.

7Ibh02R6NL3KYMXs6w0k2w.text: I'm a big fan of the Hofbrauhaus in Munich, so of course I'd love a stateside version! This is True to the Munich original, if a bit smaller in scale. Same good German beer, same good German food. If that's what you're looking for, you're in luck! If not ... I'd strongly suggest you go elsewhere.  Beer: They have the traditonal lager, a hefeweizen, and a dunkel. Each month they have a special beer of the month, and they also seem to have a 5th brewer's selection at most times. Beers come in 1/2 or full liters. That's it!  Food: My family is German, so I do love a solid German meal. I was in town on business, so I definitely took advantage of the situation to stop in. We don't have too many great German spots in my hometown, so I have to get my fill while in Pennsylvania. I had a pretzel followed by a sandwich, and I subbed in a potato dumpling for a side. Yum yum yum!  Atmosphere: Standard beerhall fare. I was there a bit early (6-730ish), so the main hall was relatively empty. There was a German musician on stage, and overall it made for a pleasant dining atmosphere. Since the crowd was pretty sparse (it was also really cold while I was there), I also had great and attentive service. I'm sure that during College Night or on the weekends, though, the place can get crowded! Perhaps not as much as elsewhere in Pittsburgh as the location seems to be pretty touristy, but I'm sure that's a draw for many.

TmeB2Jc3c3numguXZXR27Q.text: The beer and the atmosphere are the absolute best. Service is fantastic and management very attentive. Probably my favorite place to visit when bike riding in Pittsburgh.

PUdbpWw0uLlVy8VxLEtjlQ.text: So we brought about 30 people in after a wedding. No one was being belligerent or overly intoxicated, but a waitress would not serve a table because she felt they were too intoxicated. Obviously this is the establishment's decision, but after talking to the people at that table and observing their mannerisms, they were not overly intoxicated. I could have pointed out over 10 people who were more intoxicated and being louder. This was also right after the table next to them (also our group) had closed out and tipped well. That was very frustrating because we were all together. I understand supporting your employees, but If a waiter or waitress chooses to not serve a customer, they should have a manager approach the group to get their own viewpoint and make a decision on their mannerisms, if that was the case, this probably wouldn't have happened. I have heard a lot of bad things about the service here, but we have had some good experiences before so we gave you a chance, but you fell short. I will not be spending my money here again. This was ridiculous.

pOC-PY0g5ipKH2PHJ5AW5A.text: My favorite place in Pittsburgh.  Great food and great beer that are consistent no matter what night you go.  On weekends they have a live band that comes in and plays crowd favorites and people get on the table benches to dance. If you want a louder experience eat in the main beer hall, for a quieter one go to the dinning area. In the summer it's best to eat in the outdoors beer garden next to the river.

L3cZXOL3NmbhYUkIkFkyjA.text: I only stopped by briefly for a beer, so I'll keep this review short.  It was my first time going to a Hofbrauhaus restaurant and to a beer garden in general. My first impression was positive. It's a perfectly situated restaurant in Southside Pittsburgh along the Monongahela River. The combination of 1 liter beer mugs, waterfront and waitresses in Dirndls made for a jolly good time.  The environment is very conducive to casual outdoor group drinking. The outdoor area is large with numerous tables. I'm guessing the capacity of the beer garden is close to 150 people. So it's a great place for group parties as well as for taking out of town guests like me who have never been to a beer garden before.    Beer was good I guess, but nothing spectacular. At the time, it was more about quantity over quantity. I didn't get a chance to sample the food, but judging from other tables there are definitely a lot of nice options that go well with beer. Service was pretty average, but waitresses in Dirndls is a plus (maybe?).   As I mentioned before, it's a great place for the occasional group outing. However, as another reviewer mentioned, it definitely carries a huge element of novelty. It's not your neighborhood bar and is not a real cozy place to grab a drink. With that said, I will be back to try the food if I am ever in town again.

euoD4nxhIEiBtDKQ_MG-jA.text: Very good food but seating is limited during weekenda when the band is going. I highly recommend the lunch buffet during the week!

kTytve07A_oOiljjFsTx5A.text: There is now happy hour, with specials on appetizers and the standard beers! Yay! Also wanted to mention that the lunch buffet is excellent, with a great salad bar, 2 soup options, several wursts (with curry sauce available!), schnitzel, mashed potatoes, German potato salad, fried cabbage, and a rotating meat entree available for ablut $13.

Eo_NS4T6WdjI6u9G7mtWWg.text: 4.5 stars...  This is the sort of place you come for an experience.  With tall ceilings, long communal tables, and lots of warm wood work, this place feels like our imagined Bavaria. The live music simply added to the atmosphere.  The food was priced on the high end, but I don't think I've ever been to a German restaurant that wasn't. My coworker and I split a giant pretzel which was soft and warm, served with amazing cheese sauce and mustard. I ordered the Jaeger schnitzel and it did not disappoint. It was tender with a crisp, thin crust and the sauce was delicious. It was served with roasted cabbage and German potato salad. While I really enjoyed the cabbage, I wish I would have requested spaetzle instead of the potato salad.  The server was average. She answered our questions and took care of our basic needs, but seemed to be in a bad mood although she never directed it to us. I might be cranky too if I had to wear a German beer maid dress all night at work. Hah.  Go here if you want a fun dining experience!

lY5xrsA4ZJGnWDtRoDzOgw.text: The beer is delicious. Really great collection. Not sure about the food because I haven't tried it, but definitely recommend the beer.

RFNMuWqbfJHXX1758EFHgw.text: Well-known for its beer, Hofbrauhaus was originated in Munich, Germany more than four centuries ago. Today, it's considered the world's most famous beer hall. Lucky for me, I don't have to go all the way to Germany... with only seven hours drive from NYC, I was able to experience the traditional Hofbrauhaus food and beer in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania.   Hofbrauhaus indoor dining room features traditional decors with nightly live entertainment, whereas outdoor dining area provides fresh breeze and relaxing water view.  Must-try includes world famous freshly brewed biers (of course), Oktoberfest schweinshaxe, braised classic pork shank and potato pancake. Good eats and hearty meals! Can't wait to come here for Oktoberfest!

yTesNgol_ZZyPUcPrda-Tw.text: This place is quite the unique experience. Only been here a couple times, and while I don't personally enjoy this type of environment too much, it can be good fun once in a while (or even just for people watching). There's seating both indoors and outdoors-sih (the latter like a patio but not really outside in the cold air), and you can choose to be as close to or as far away from the revelry as you want. Come later at night and people will be drinking and singing, and oftentimes dancing on the benches.   As for the beers and the food, they are quite passable. My personal favorite is the hefeweizen, but they also offer several other standard varieties. There is a lot of German fare food, from wurst to pretzels to salads to various entrees. While I don't personally think they are amazing, they all do go very well with the beer.

eIYwIxMvuFOpFMJU7kCbhQ.text: 5 stars all the way!! The servers were cute in their clothing and not slutty in my opinion. I know slutty. I've been to the Tilted Kilt. The place was clean, the service was good, and it wasn't too noisy nor were people disgusting drunk. With that out of the way...  The food was awesome. I heart the hell out of German food, and this did the trick. We shared the sauerkraut balls, which were scrumptious. We each had the Oktoberfest Schweinshaxe, which was colossal and amazing. It looked like a dinosaur leg!! We had leftovers for two days. It came with crackling (a southern thing too, something this southern girl knows about), potato dumpling, and more of that good sauerkraut.   Dessert was the apple strudel for me, and it was superb. I don't remember having the pretzel, though. Darren hogged that. lol. I also loved the Prince Ludwig beer.   All in all, Hofbrahaus is a great addition to South Side Works.

zUplAqzbepO2wymOEz-gmA.text: LOVE this place. I had such a fun time there and I don't even drink beer. The cocktails are pretty good. The bartenders can make pretty much anything. They had some good food there as well. The table dancing was my favorite part of my night there.

PdHrVNEgPicGAVfHvomv0g.text: Love the litre of Dunkel and the nice soft pretzels to go with all that beer! Nice, festive atmosphere -- what one would expect in a place like this. Absolute chaos on the weekends, however, I prefer weeknights and the outdoor patio for an excellent view of the river.

ASgziNGXdJiII5DrZaiBdQ.text: I can't help but feel like someone brought me to German Disneyland. The outfits (Dirndl) for the waitresses make me feel sad and embarrassed (but...also impressed by their cleavage). How come the bros get by in just a white and blue button up? Well, at least the dude playing the "accordion" (it was a piano) was in legit lederhosen. Work it, German Santa. He played some folk-ish music including Edelweiss. I drank their Doppelbock. It was tasty. It was 8.0% but I could REALLY taste the alcohol more than with other Doppelbocks I've had. I like that they have the ABV on there and also describe the beer. I could see the appeal of this place for Oktoberfest but I think I'll stay away until then. There's better beer to be had that doesn't subject their female waitstaff to dress like beer wenches.

FgMpBMJnOdvNRswDxACHpw.text: No disrespect to those who have come here and had a great time -- I am sure it's possible.  I mean who doesn't love 2490589348 people standing on top of tables smashing their beer mugs (that must weigh ten pounds) together---constant toasting---all while those same people sing a Bruce Springstein song as good as they can for as drunk as they are.    This place is huge -- surely it could fit half the population of Pittsburgh.  It's unique, too, I'll give you that.  And the beer prices aren't half bad!  But let's get real.  I thought two things over and over again when I was here: 1.  Did a frat house rent this place out for a party?  I found out, no..... Says the girl next to me, "It's always like this". 2.  Is this a Tea Party gathering?  Evidence indicates no, it wasn't, so again "it's always like this".

X4TxjBKR4-wud-49dsQasw.text: Pretzels & bier cheese + potato pancakes! Yum. The other things I have tried, including the sauerkraut balls, fried pickles, sample platter of wursts and schnitzel were just okay.  I won't be back anytime soon, mainly because I prefer more intimate dining settings. I came here on a double date and we were yelling across the table because it was so loud. I guess that's part of the experience.

NxBpDvU19tIdhAnRGAtr0w.text: I came here last night for a private party.  Because this wasn't the standard setup, there wasn't table service--rather, food was served in a buffet line and drinks were served at the bar.  Most of the available food was fried (not sure if this is the case for the regular menu).  I tried the pretzels with bier cheese, fried sauerkraut balls, fried pickles, and fried chicken nugget things (they probably have an actual name, but I don't know what it is).  The first thing I noticed was how extremely salty all of the food was.  This was particularly True of the pretzels, and the source was the bier cheese, surprisingly.  Indeed, it became so overwhelmingly salty that by my second pretzel, I started using the Gulden's mustard at the table to cut it, which helped tremendously.  Quite frankly, due to this problem, I was disappointed in the pretzels and cheese, which I'd heard was HBH's signature appetizer.  My favorite of the foods that I tried was the sauerkraut balls, which were still salty, but at least had some tanginess due to the vinegar.  The chicken and pickles were pretty nondescript.  There was also apple strudel for dessert, which was okay, but not great.  Not surprisingly, I was thirsty after eating all of the extremely salty food, so I ordered a cherry cosmopolitan to wash it down.  I did really enjoy this drink, which was quite delicious and refreshing after all the salt I'd just ingested.  While I'm aware that most people come to HBH for the beer, I'm not a beer drinker, so I was a bit concerned that only beer would be available for drinks.  However, I was pleasantly surprised by the breadth of the drink menu, which included several cocktails, shots, and wines in addition to the beer.  As others have commented, aside from the beer, the ambiance is what really defines HBH.  There was live music playing most of the time I was there, which consisted of a (strange) mix of traditional German songs and covers of '80's music.  Many of the attendees got into singing the covers and did the whole standing on the bench thing, which was fun.  Because of this, it was quite loud in the beer hall most of the time, but I was able to escape this when I tired of it by going out to the balcony, which has a nice view of the river.  Like Mad Mex, HBH is a theme restaurant that people come to to have a rowdy good time with the help of some liquid libation.  However, also like Mad Mex, the quality of the food leaves something to be desired, so don't go there expecting a great meal.  I'm glad I experienced it once, but I wouldn't go out of my way to return unless a group of my friends wanted to come.

t5JoLYtObxHkcx4r1izcZA.text: I was apprehensive about how I thought our night would go.  We came for a 21st birthday dinner at 5:30, and didn't get seated til 7pm.  They do not take reservations and even though my husband called and talked to a manager who said they'd do their best to accommodate us, no one passed the word onto the evening manager, so our group of 21 sat waiting for 2 tables.  Once that was done, we all had a great time.  The waitress was sympathetic to our older folks sitting right in front of the 'band' and didn't mind repeating things two and three times to our group.  We got our beers / drinks quickly and really enjoyed the loud, chaotic atmosphere.  There were mostly families and large groups when we were there, I assume the crowd changes drastically after 9pm.  The food was good - no problem substituting spaetzle for potato salad (I find their kartoffel salat a bit too sweet).  I had the Jagerschnitzel which I thought was pretty good.  The potato pancakes were a little over-fried (according to some of our guests at the table).  I've had the wurst platters and they are pretty good.  All in all, if you're up for a loud, adventurous night and meeting total strangers, you'll enjoy the Hofbrauhaus.  We did a lot of singing, shot-skis and just had an all around fun time.

HIcOxUMDFmiGZ1NK2RrIfw.text: I was in town visiting my fiancee's old stomping grounds, and we stumbled on this place.  I got the Sauerbraten and I'm still unsure if I liked it. It was like nothing I'd had before so was unique in that way. Just not sure if I like German food or not. I think I liked it. My fiancee and her father had some other dishes which they were quite pleased with, but the joy was the music. We were there on a Saturday night and there was an accordion band in the front singing their hearts out. They even sang Sweet Caroline, which being a Boston native I had to sing along with. and yet, there was a room full of Pittsburghers singing along! It was a blast.  They also had a special where if you ordered a liter of beer, you got to keep the mug, so I'll always have a memento of Hofbrauhaus in the form of an enormous mug.

y6Hg1yR3xLTGQB7dkAOxuA.text: So my review of the food may or may not really be accurate, considering that I'm a huge lightweight when it comes to beer. I had one stein's worth and... at that point everything tastes delicious to me.  I was visiting a friend who goes to school in Grove City and she said that the Hofbrauhaus was a must-visit place in Pittsburgh. My other friend and I got off the airplane from NYC at 9PM and the three of us headed straight for this place for some dinner and beer.  We went just when Storm Khan was rushing through, though I guess Pittsburgh was relatively safe. The parking was pretty far and the walk kind of sucked. What sucked more was by the time we got there and were pulling out our IDs, my friend from NY realized she didn't have her ID on her, so we had to walk back to the car. The bouncer laughed at us and led us in.  Oh jeez, I have never been to a crazier beer garden. People were screaming along to songs on the top of their lungs, dancing on benches and swinging their steins. We were really hungry, so we opted to sit in a booth so that we could also talk. Basically, whenever the band paused, we would squeeze as much conversation as we could before being overwhelmed by sound again. It seemed like everyone was having a great time. The general ambiance was really impressive!  The food and beers were great! We ordered the Hofbrauhaus Pretzels for our appetizers, and the three of us got the Jaegerschnitzel (me), the pork loin special, and Hofbrauhaus Wurstplatte. The Jaegershnitzel was DELICIOUS. Omg, it was like honestly the best breaded pork cutlet I have eaten in my life. It was very soft on the inside, yet the skin was crunchy and flavorful. The portions were pretty big too. The German potato salad was interesting (more like scalloped potatoes) and the pickled cabbage was delectable, even though I am not a fan of anything pickled. My friend's pork loin was tender and juicy. I'm always scared of pork loins because usually they get too dried out, but this one was good, along with the mashed potatoes! The Wurstplatte was interesting. There were three different types of sausages, which I do not remember what they are called. I like the white one the best because it was so soft, almost like a fish sausage. It wasn't sharp and salty like normal sausages.  The pretzels were very salty (waaaay too much rock pieces on them) and the cheese was salty as well, but I don't like pretzels in general so I didn't dock any points off since I have a bias against them anyway. I ordered a stein of the Hofbrau Premium Lager, which was light and delicious. I think I got tipsy so quickly because I hadn't eaten anything else that whole day to prepare myself for this place. My Pitt friend ordered the Hofbrau Weizen, which was a bit too banana-y for my tastes, though the other two insisted that it was the best beer they had ever had. It was good, but not my favorite.  In general this place is a great experience. If you like rowdy crowds, friendly waiters, and great German food, this place is for you!

ZP904amZiRg2828BOqQmAQ.text: Every time I come to Pittsburgh, I make sure to go to Hofbrauhaus! For any German beer fan who has been living under a rock, Hofbrauhaus is a German Biergarten in Munich.  Each time I come to Hofbrauhaus, I make sure to try one of their seasonal beers. So far, I have tried the Weizenbock, Bavarian Wheat and the Marzen. Outside of this, I have tried most of their other beers with the Weizen being my favorite. The great thing about the Hofbrauhaus in Pittsburgh is the fact that they brew their beers there! This means you will always get a fresh beer!  As for the food; the food is always great! It's a little expensive; however, the portions are huge! When I go, I always split the Schmankerlplatte with someone. This plate consists of Schweinsbraten, Smoked Pork Chops, three kinds of Wursts, Sauerkraut, Fried Cabbage, and Mashed Potatoes. It's huge! Everything on it is great!  My only complaint with this place is the lack of parking; however, this is an issue pretty much anywhere you go in Pittsburgh.

jml6y13DWqqKhv16RtXFDg.text: The beer is good, yet the food is underwhelming. My husband really loves the beer, a redeeming quality, but otherwise this place is a 2 star in my book. The service was slow when we went, the food didn't come fast or hot. I'll avoid my snobbery, but as someone that is of German descent, and has visited Germany, all of the food we tried is a sad representation. I know most people are interested in the experience, which Hofbrauhaus provides, but if you're interested in delicious German food, find a grandma and save yourself heartbreak.

-ulULE-54gTF1SFIXb-sJQ.text: We had the sampler app which consisted of two pretzels, two potato pancakes, fried pickles (whaaaa?), and some kind of sour kraut ball. It was good. NxBuYPiBWAmholACmMNZsg.text: Don't come here for the food.  It's friggin' German food with cheese sauce galore.  Great beer though.  I don't like anything but the Dunkel, but maybe you'll find one you like.  The rotating selection is nice for a surprise sometimes -- and any place that serves a litre deserves a thumbs up.  Good sausage, potatoes, but the cheese sauce is a bowel wrecker.

ezXl8SpmiaYmT8vYjvJY1A.text: I normally like this place.  Enough that I bought a GROUPON.  Read the Fine Print!  I should have known the Groupon did not include alcoholic beverages.  I paid $13 for $25 value.  My main problem is that the staff was not trained to counsel their customer (like me) that once the Groupon was redeemed, the problem could not be fixed. She said the same thing.  CAVEAT EMPTOR.  Aka, Buyer Beware!  She told me once Groupon is redeemed, it can not be altered.  I recommended that she have a team meeting with her staff to train them better for the next patron.  Once again, she had the audacity to tell me, YOU didn't read the fine print.  I got her message loud and clear.  I told her, I understand clearly her position and that it must have been 100% my fault.  Bon Appetit.  I won't be spending any more of my money at this joint.  There are far too many other restaurants that would love my cash.

DjGkay-ErVr9uLjE20Z0PA.text: If a large crowd of people standing on benches at long tables in a beer hall, dancing and waving gigantic mugs of German brew back and forth as they listen to a cheesy cover band is your idea of a good time, then Hofbrauhaus is the place for you.   I have a soft spot for a place where everyone is encouraged to party, and this place is just that. We went there on a Saturday night on a recent trip to Pittsburgh and the place was jam-packed and everyone was having fun.   The place is a little "white" ethnically speaking, music-wise, etc. The live band played old cover songs you'd probably hear at weddings, e.g., Neil Diamond, Billy Joel, etc.  You will find yourself singing along.   Beer is brewed there, and is good and cheap -- the  liters were about $8. The wheat beer was nice, so was the lager.  We didn't have the food, so I can't comment on that.  Go with a group of friends. It's a fun place!

dogUAgFfgzwc1VJCGF9cVQ.text: Came here on a friend's recommendation. After paying for (mandatory) valet parking, we went in and asked for a table for two. Hostess looks at me as if I am off my rocker for thinking that we could get seated for dinner (at 9 pm!) and says, "We aren't taking names any more tonight, but if you want to wait about an hour, we switch to open seating."  Open seating, as she further explains, means that at that point, we will have to wander the restaurant looking for an empty table, fight our way to it, hope no one else grabs it before we can get there, and then wait to have a server notice us.   We took one glance at the frat-boys and already-drunk cougars and decided to try one of the other places near by.   I don't care if they have the best German food on Earth (and looking at the priorities of the clientele, I'm guessing they don't) such lousy service is not going to win my business when there are so many other options in this town.

HGOb5ftNHagy8kGKGubBCg.text: I admit that I've been putting off a trip to Hofbrauhaus for a long time. It wasn't that I was against going there, per say, but my absolute hatred of the South Side Works and what is offered there--both establishments and personalities--made me think I would loath it just because of its location. But my affinity for beer, especially beer in giant glass mugs, and the fact that it was the location of one of my good friends 25th birthday party celebration finally brought me in.  I arrived sometime around 11 on a Friday night to a line circling around the side of the building. At once I thought my fears were confirmed, a long line of what I perceived to be South Side douche bags. But as I got closer I realized that it wasn't just a bunch of frat boys in line, but there were people of all ages and all walks of life waiting to get in. On top of that the line moved very quickly and all in all only spent about five minutes waiting to get inside.  Once inside I made my way to the bar area, which was much more spacious than I thought it would be. That being said, Hofbrauhaus was still extremely crowded leaving little room to stand without bumping in to someone or having someone bump in to you. The dense crowd also left long waits for beer. The bartending staff tried their best to keep up, but there is only so much they can do when you have hundreds of people making human sardines around the bar all trying to order a beer at the same time.  I ordered a liter of Dunkel, and when it was finally served to me, tasted pretty good. I'm not all that familiar with German style beers so I'm in no position to comment on its quality, but from an amateur perspective I thought it possessed a strong and unique flavor. The price for a liter wasn't bad, especially considering the location of Hofbrauhaus. I believe the "big mug" ran somewhere between $7 and $8. I wish I would have had more time to try a few of the other brews but I didn't get the chance.  The atmosphere of Hofbrauhaus is a bit more rowdy than I expected. Long rows of thick wooden tables and benches line the open space between the bar and the stage which aren't used for sitting but instead standing upon. From this perch one feels like he or she is the life of the party singing songs and swinging mugs about, beer sloshing out like a geyser.  The band was lively, fun, dressed in authentic Bavarian dress, and I could tell they really did have a passion for the music they were playing, but I was really hoping for something a big more authentic. Most of the songs they played were American covers, nothing but a few songs were German.  My experience at Hofbrauhaus was a lot better than I originally thought it would be. It wasn't as much of a corporate juggernaut bar like many of the other bars in the South Side Works area, even though the amount of people they allow to be packed in at once makes you wonder if they care more about their profits or the experiences of their patrons. Will I come back? Probably yes, but only from time to time. I much prefer smaller less crowded and noisy bars, but if I have to pick a larger venue bar Hofbrauhaus would be the place.

I've always sat outside when going here and I think it's great to be out in the open drinking some good ol' German beer.    Having been to the original Hof in Munich I can tell you it's very authentic.  The food from what I've tasted is good and the beer is delicious - I prefer Hefeweizen's so I can't comment on the other type of beers.     Seeing that this is one of three Hofbrauhaus' in the U.S. (Cincinnatti, Las Vegas, Pittsburgh), Pittsburghers should feel proud to have the opportunity to experience this wonderful place.  So grab some friends and grab a beer at the Hof - and try the pretzels with some beer cheese - delish!

1NLLYEsEk6OQ0TCE0bWRLg.text: Went here during Octoberfest with a bunch of close friends where we all had a blast. Best part was everyone was on top of their bench singing along with the band! Traditional beer garden with excellent seating both outdoor and indoor.

Z_J9Uyy0XNeg8opsz580xg.text: Great classic German foods, my dad said that the potato pancakes were comparable to the ones his German grandma used to make many years ago! Very fun on Thursdays when it's college night and they have $6 liters of beer. It's a great place

IavfYWo0gcusZ_hoznu32w.text: This was actually our first stop in Pittsburgh, so I guess I should have reviewed this first! Oops!   My friend tells me that Hofbrauhaus is ALWAYS a staple for him to take his out-of-town visitors. The first things that you'll notice even before you enter the building are the beer silos. Yup, they brew their own beers, which makes it cheap for you and me! The next thing you'll notice are.. the bewbs. The ladies who work here don't wear a complete skimpy outfit like they do at Hooters or Tilted Kilt, etc. but they do show off their top heavy bosoms. Very nice. ;)  We came around 8 and my friend immediately requested that we sat inside when we were asked. Why? Wait till around 9PM and you'll see. Okay, impatient? I'll tell yinz (yes, I did pick up on some of their slang)! Around 9 or maybe 9:30, the Haus Band comes on and plays every type of song under the sun, ranging from The Lion sleeps Tonight to Call Me Maybe. Surprisingly, there was a good bit of country music thrown in the mix. Everything was well received by the audience, who seemed to know every word of every song they played. When you throw together people who know how to have a good time, plus a flow of cheap beer, plus a very good band who knows how to play just about every song you can think of and seems to get better the more they drink, what do you get? Everyone dancing their butts off on top of their benches. It is quite a site to see and an experience you must have in life. My friend did give us a disclaimer that if we wanted to talk about anything that evening, to get it out right away because we won't get an opportunity to later. He was right! Lol.  As if all of that wasn't entertaining enough, there's this REALLY old guy who makes an appearance almost every night. He comes out a little bit after the band does and dances with every pretty lady in the building. Some of his risque moves though.. yeah, he gets away with it because he's an old guy haha. Let me tell ya, he's a hoot and a half! I've got some interesting photos and videos to prove it.  So, aside from the bustling festivities, I thought the food was just okay but the beau and friends all loved what they got. Definitely opt for their in-house brewed beers and pay a little extra to keep a [brand new, never used] souvenir pint glass to take home.  We were stuffed and tired from all the singing and dancing, but my friend took us outside behind the pub and showed us the beer garden, which was very peaceful and romantic (surprisingly). It has a fantastic view of the river and looks even more amazing with the reflection of the city lights bouncing off from it. If you're wanting to grab some authentic German grub, but are not in the mood to burn off all those calories just yet, opt to sit outside.

-_3MYGlX9Lv0XSH3SuUqTw.text: Just went here for the first time with my family.  This place is a good time, but if you don't like the idea of an Oktoberfest kind of place with everyone drinking giant liter beers, then don't go here.  The food was good and they really stick to the German types of food.  I had a sampler of some of the wursts and pork roasts.  It was prepared to my liking and tasty.  There wasn't anything that would blow you away, but if you like German food it's a great place.  There were even some things on the menu I've never had before that were fun to try like sauerkraut balls and fried pickles.   I enjoyed their beer as well.  They have a different seasonal brew every month as well as their regulars.  All were good and stick to the German brewing rules.  For comparison though, I liked what I had here better than the similar beers one would find at Gordon Biersch.  Oh yeah, having four people do a shot off a ski in front of the whole place is a good time.  We actually had our kids along and they did great.  Plus the place is so damn loud they can make all the noise they want.  The live music was also a neat experience.  Long story short, I'd like to come back without any kids and get hammered with the crowd there that I can guess gets rowdy as the night goes on.

s02CgizVognrlySvaoe2wA.text: Decent traditional German food?  Check.  Delicious German beer?  Check.  Polka music?  Check!!!  Need I say more?  Probably not, but I'm going to anyway.  This place is really fun to visit with good buddies and to get a bit of a buzz.  Will the food knock your socks off?  Probably not especially, though it certainly isn't bad food.  Is the beer ground-breaking?  Not exactly, but it tastes good, fresh, cold, and comes in large and ridiculously large (always a good choice).  Are there many other places out there where you can drink and hear live polka music?  Very few!  Enjoy the atmosphere, have a sausage, and drink a beer.  You'll feel better after you do.

SXCCk4nkW6kuPK-v8Y9H-A.text: Love it here.  The sheer size of the space, and the pervasiveness and tastefulness of the theme, are impressive enough that I sometimes forget how great the food and drink are.  Their seasonal beers are terrific, and of course the Hefeweisen is a solid standby.  The pretzels will blow your mind, and the sauerbraten, spaetzle, and wursts are all pitch-perfect.  I give it four stars because the size, crowds, and noise can get kind of overwhelming to me - a personal preference, I admit!  I give them lots of credit for stepping outside the wurst-and-kraut standards to provide the schnitzel cordon bleu (which, beware: it's way cheesier than you expect!) and the Heidelberger Rahm Spaetzle, a kind of creamy chicken-and-spaetzle marsala that I order when I don't feel like moving for the next few hours.  I'd say Hofbrauhaus is a must-visit!

GHZdg2GBqPbGPG2-1LE_tA.text: We arrived shortly after 8, to a line.  We waited, and when we checked in with the hostess, we gave our cell number and were told it would be a 30 minute wait.  An hour and 15 minutes later, we were still waiting.  I went in and asked again how long it would be, and a second hostess said that the kitchen backed up, and that they just started seating again, and it would be another 20 minutes.   I wish someone had told us from the outset that they weren't seating, and that the estimated wait was over 90 minutes. We would have went elsewhere instead of waiting around.  Or, since they did have our cell number, someone could have sent a text explaining the situation.   Needless to say, we never did try the food because we didn't want to wait any longer just to be seated....from the complaints of others that we could over hear, food was taking a long time as well.  If the kitchen can't handle the volume of orders coming back, perhaps they shouldn't seat so many at one time.  I understand that things happen, but you have to be up front with customers, and not let people wait way longer than they are expecting to with no explanation.  Seems like it would be a good place, but this situation left a sour taste in my mouth, and I doubt we will return.

84WVLhEQzczZRAgZ0bIWfQ.text: I have to give this place a split personality review.  The party side of me says this place is a heck of a good time!  The foodie side of me says this place compares to a TGIFridays, but with German food.   The first time I came here was right after they opened....so I wanted to come for the food and drink.  It was the dead of winter so the outdoor area wasn't open yet and we were shoved in the corner of the large dining room.  I couldn't decide what to order because I love sauerkraut, I love cabbage and I love German Potato Salad!  It's sad I didn't even want any of the meats, all sides!  So I just stuck to those and apps.  I mean who can go wrong with those choices??   So the fried pickles were good and....fried.  Check.  The sauerkraut was like mush.  Ew.  I expect good sauerkraut from a German place!  I want it crisp and tart.  Just plain mush.  The German Potato salad, mushy as well.  Potato's, mushy....no flavor.  Yuck.  Fried Cabbage...you hear me....FRIED....was mush!  Seriously, horrible!  I would never come here to eat again.    On the other side....   Atmosphere is fantastic! The dining room is really rambunctious! They have people standing on tables and singing.  they have a HUGE shot luge where a bunch of people have to take shots at once.  And the outside...FANTASTIC!  It's this huge open area with picnic tables and a large bar.  Plus you're right smack against the river so it's really pretty out to.  Pretty for a beer garden I suppose!  The beer comes in these huge liters, which is great in theory, but if you're not slamming them back it gets warm and nasty.  I'm always a lager fan, so I had the Hofbrau Premium Lager.  It was pretty much lager like.  Nothing to write home to Germany about.   So remember, food gross but drinking atmosphere GREAT!

hGnGlG2BCESCkK5xbygqZQ.text: The experience of walking into this river-front homage to a traditional German bier hall feels less like my idea of Oktoberfest in Munich and more like Bill Murray's life a la Groundhog Day.  I can say this because I've been there 3-4 times and the story always plays out the same way...it's up to you to somehow drive the plot in a different direction.  Perhaps I'm missing the point...after all we return to most establishments seeking a consistent and memorable investment of our time and money...but I like to think we as Pittsburghers take more pride in our small locally owned watering holes than the same hoopla you'd find at Busch Gardens.    There is no formal parking lot at the Hofbrauhaus, just several nearby multi-level parking garages and a handful of metered spots in and around the Southside Works complex.  Chances are you'll pay something to park within walking distance.    Once inside everything seems larger than life...the tall ceilings, medieval sized tables that seat dozens, the shameless display of cleavage, and most of all...my disdain for boring and flavorless lagers.  I'll admit...I am a total beer snob...always hunting down the hoppiest of imperial IPA, but I will gladly find comfort in a nice malty dopplebock if it's available.  Alas, i've learned from the Seasonal release schedule that February is the only time of year when the style is on tap.   The food is exactly what you'd hope for; variations of wursts, schnitzels, potato pancakes and pretzels as well as some "American" choices - Burgers, Salads, etc.  It's the cavalade of starch and sausage that you'd want while eating cafeteria style to the tune of Journey's "Don't stop believing" honked out on accordion.    Who doesn't like to have their meal-time conversation interrupted by yinzers of all ages shouting a mispronounced "ZICKE ZACKE"  atop the same wooden benches that make it near impossible to "shimmy" yourself out to use the restroom.    Though I've never taken part in a shot-ski...I get the appeal.  The overall sense of merriment at the Hofbrau is perfect for getting large groups together as an impersonal celebration of special events, birthdays and a place to party with absolute strangers on any given weeknight.  For my money, I'll stick to Penn Brewery to get my fix of German fare with house-made brews...but thats just me; The hop-head whose personal nightmare is accepting being just a predictable part of the crowd.

qOeBNFERmkHC1-M_-zvCTA.text: Not a beer person, but if you are, make a stop here and I'm almost guaranteed that you'll like it. When I came here with my bf, I felt like we entered a German village. The performances were great, the place was HUGE, and the crowd was just one big happy family.

K-m54wdDsFNDINsb96BoZw.text: Hofbrauhaus is such a fun concept and is situated in an amazing location right on the water. Walking in, you're overcome by the cute outfits that the staff is wearing, the authentic decor and homey feeling. This location is big and perfect for large groups I like the biergarten concept outside. All of the beers that I have tried have been great. Service is generally pretty good--not over the top fantastic, but no complaints. Avoid the food. It is GROSS. I've tried 4 different items and hated all of them. I guess Germany isn't known for their food, so why should this place be any different? They do not have a happy hour (at least in the beer garden), so don't expect any deals on their pricey pints.

T74W6FBzsETrS5oDLn0cwA.text: I have been here several times to enjoy the beer and music, but hadn't eaten here until recently. I was pleasantly surprised! We started with the pretzels and bier cheese. In general I am not a bug pretzel fan but these were great. And the cheese sauce was AMAZING - I would have eaten it with a soon if I had one. For my entree I had the Wurstplatte, which is a sampler of the bierwurst, bratwurst, and frankfurter. The food in general is pretty heavy, but I still managed to clean my plate. The wursts were very good, and the sides of mashed potatoes and sauerkraut were delicious.  This is not the kind of place I could be a regular at, but it is definitely a great spot to enjoy every so often, and it is great for groups. While the music can be pretty loud, there are enough tables further back that you can still partake in the fun while enjoying conversation at the same time.

rlVbEM-EJ6_h2IgoijxMZw.text: Wonderful food & great service. Not sure if reservations are possible, but try to call ahead. Fun atmosphere and delicious good if you are a fan of German cuisine, which I am. Was looking forward to some cucumber salad or bloodwurst but alas it is not in the menu. Oh - great beer too! Will make this a regular stop when in PA in the future!!

jg-iXO3-s0xpqj2GvqUWfQ.text: Some may claim heresy, but I for one am a huge fan of the new Hofbrahaus.  As much as I liked to go and have as many liters of beer and shotski's as my body pleased back in the day, Hofbra became such a party destination recently that the mood had transitioned from a community feeling of fun to a drunk titanic weighting down the South Side.  With the new ID requirements, drink limits, and elimination of a few of the drinking rituals of past, you can actually go to Hofbra on a Friday or Saturday night to relax and have a genuinely good time.  The beer is, as always, historic to the traditional ways of German brewing.  No crazy variations or additions here...  Water, Malt, Hops, and Yeast.  Done.  For those looking for more adventurous craft offerings, you'll likely disappointed.  However, if you have a True appreciation for German offerings, Hofbra is a great asset to the city in that regard.  The food overall is decent.  Nothing to write home about, but the pretzels and beer cheese make a fantastic drinking companion.  Overall, Hofbra continues to be a great destination for locals and out of towners alike (still one of only three or four in the country I believe!).

Their steaks are fantastic, sandwiches, dinners are to die for.  The beer that they serve is fantastic as well...even if you don't drink, you should start if you go there!  LOL  Definitely one of my favorites....

AXtxiz5eEQbrhY540eQ1GQ.text: I have almost never turned down a trip to the Hofbrauhaus.  Check that--I don't think I *ever* have.  I am a confirmed Germanophile, so there's that.  But, what I really like about going there is the atmosphere of gemutlichkeit (geniality, friendliness) that I have experienced myself in Germany.  It's fun sitting at bench seats with a dozen of your friends, drinking from glass steins the size of your forearm, singing "Sweet Caroline" for the seventh time, and I've never had a meal that I didn't like.  Hard to miss on good old fashioned meat and potatoes cooking, although it would be nice to see German style salads, which are completely underrated and amazing.  But, overall, it's a fun place whether you're indoors with the din of commotion or out on the more subdued patio, or the outdoor biergarten next to the river.

B0P_eUObUgYQXBG6fHiMEg.text: Pros: Beer was very good  Cons: Food tastes like frozen and what I can buy in the grocery store - expensive tourist trap  I was told if I were in Pittsburgh, this place is a must.  The service here was top notch.  We were a party of four and Chris was very attentive and knowledgable about the beer.  I got the sampler, which ran under $8 for 5 beers. What a deal!  They were all good.   The food was nothing special. The pretzel appetizer was too salty.  My pierogies tasted like Mrs. T's.  They were supposed to have bacon and chives, but all I got were pierogies with sour cream and onion straws.  We were there for the trivia night, which was enjoyable. During that, I got the nacho appetizer.  Again, nothing special.  The food is extremely overpriced for the quality.  You can phone in the German music and mead hall atmosphere, but it doesn't fix the food.  Go for the beer...after going to dinner at the Cheesecake Factory across the street.

TkX5Xm8mH4IRIjBs1_7PNw.text: Appetizers were really good. Chicken was good but thick cut. Live music was great one of the best atmospheres in south side. Right on the river and great service.

kMkSA302xh4Iy783C2wTEQ.text: I sincerely wanted to like this place.  I have been there 4 or 5 times, always with the same result: exceptionally below average.   The ambience is cute, with the waiters in Lederhosen and the waitresses in drindles, and a seemingly-authentic menu.  The beer is above average, but barely.   Now to the food.  Without the beer, I would give zero stars.  Absolutely horrendous.  The few standouts were the fried cabbage and weisswurst.   The weiner schnitzel was well below average.  The kraut was cold and bland.  "imported" or not.  The pork cutlets were so incredibly dry that even gravy couldn't save them.  Cute try at a German bierhall, but the food is awful.  If you are looking for authentic German fare without the Lederhosen and tacky decorations, go to Max's Allegheny Tavern on the North Side.  They have been doing it well since 1903, when the area was called "Deutschtown" because of the large number of German immigrants.

zPu3Kvf9l0lrC0gs9bm4Kg.text: The atmosphere is solid. The music is a bit loud for a dinner scene. Beer is great. The food is OK - not the best German that I have had in Pittsburgh.

LHcHsGORky30L8rKTMqaBA.text: In all honesty, this place almost got a bad review if the food wasn't so damn good. My cousin took us here. Three of us are over 21 and the fourth is 19. It is a restaurant that serves a lot of really good beer and amazing German food.   Oddly enough and it makes no sense to me, after 9pm they won't let anyone under 21 inside so there was a moment when things felt really stressful. We then learned we could eat in the restaurant on one side we just couldn't eat on the side with the live music and where the bar was.   When we got our table the hostess was incredibly rude. There was a table with three women on one end and 5 empty chairs on the other end of the same table. The dining room we were in was practically empty so I still don't understand why the hostess tried to sit us at the same table with three total strangers? The women at the table gave her the funniest side eyed look I have seen. Then she puts us at the empty table just one row over but it was missing a chair. Instead of taking the chair from the adjacent table, she marched over to the table where the three women were and yanked one of the chairs from the table making a commotion with this awful pissed off look on her face. Slammed it under our table and walked off. We joked with each other that we should have offered to get the chair for her, maybe it wasn't in her job description or maybe she knew and didn't like the three women at the table.   Then comes in cute little blond girl with glasses and a smile from ear to ear. She is our waitress. Super friendly, offered advice when we asked about menu items and overall had a great personality.  OMG! When the food came I was in HEAVEN! The BEST Perogies I have ever had, I do not like cabbage but I LOVED the cabbage here. It was cooked and seasoned so well I could have eaten it all night.   We walked across to the other side after dinner, took a few facebook live videos of the band and everyone standing and dancing on their tables. It was a great experience. Then we went back to the restaurant side to pick up our 19 year old friend. LOL  I recommend going here for sure, if you have minors with you under 21 try and go before 9pm. The strange thing is when I walked across into that area, there were families with children in there but our 19 year old friend wasn't allowed after 9? So if we would have gotten there at 8:30 and stayed until 11:00 he could have gone on that side so it does seem a little strange, but those are the rules.
