j2N6X6i-9B-6msEoTd6AMA.text: We went here after biking, which may have been a bad choice because the beers are ginormous! Let me tell you, I had trouble riding my bike back after just one... The beer itself was just standard, nothing special, but it seemed a little too easy to drink a beer the size of my head... so they have something going for them.   All we go to eat was pretzels, and they were good, but also nothing too special. I think that the important thing here is that nothing is too expensive, you can sit outside on the river, and the beers are as big as your head!

txWWuEHv7zM4G2NxmJJitQ.text: We were pretty disappointed in our visit to the Hofbrauhaus. I hadn't been there in years and mom has never been but we checked it out. It was Father's Day, so we knew it'd be busy. We grabbed 2 seats at the bar vs waiting the 20-30 min for a table. Initially, our bartender/server, Sara, was timely and responsive but over time, this attention all but disappeared. The bar seats were all taken but I did notice that the people to my right had a different server than we did. We ordered within 10 min of sitting, including an appetizer, and our beers were brought out in a normal timeframe. However, after at least 30-40 min, we asked Sara where our pierogies were and she made a face that told me she forgot about them and said she'd go check. When she returned, she had the app and stated the plate was very hot, an indication it had been sitting in the heat window for quite some time. The pierogies were very hard to break apart with the fork, as thick flour/potato might be when it's been microwaved or sitting in a heat lamp for too long. Then, after another at least 40 min, we asked where our meals were. Sara said the kitchen was pretty backed up but when we pointed out that the ppl next to us (who arrived 20 min after we ordered) and the table of 6 behind us who also sat after us had received their meals, she said she'd send the manager over. The manager heard our same complaint about others getting their food long before us, he went back to the kitchen to check on our order and came back with it about 5-10 min later. The food had very obviously been replated. Mom had ordered roast chicken and I a bratwurst hotdog, both with potato salad. The plates were cold and the chicken and bratwurst were both lukewarm - not freshly cooked so I'm assuming they'd been sitting in heat lamp for so long but they had to change plates due to their heat. We were never spoken to by Sara again. The manager took our beers off the tab and 2 separate servers checked on us while we ate. I don't think I'd be as irritated or disappointed if Sara had just held herself accountable for forgetting about us with both the app and the meals. She just seemed very nonchalant and unphased by the busy-ness around her. I don't know if others in her station were waiting this long but it was definitely noticeable her lack of attention vs others in the bar area. The beer and atmosphere were nice but this experience was too disappointing and we likely won't be back.

AvIoYDLZTXcrcnUNFBY8xw.text: Man o man, what can i say? Took 15 minutes to get a beer bartenders werent terribly busy, just oblivious. sQ3qFb4Xm17o3kOc6iWAEQ.text: Cheers!  I love coming to the Hofbrauhaus  on a Saturday or Sunday afternoon.  Most especially when it is nice enough to enjoy the outdoor biergarten along with the views of the city and the river.  Maybe it's the German in me, or the beer in me, or the German beer in me?  Eh either way you put it, I'm down with it.  Now I haven't eaten here but on a few occasions.   The food is good enough.  No particular stars or duds that I can recall.  I love German food, but their version is much more Americanized.  It's okay though, since the South Side offers so much in the way of eateries I am happy to just come and spend a couple hours in the sun downing a liter of brew.     Our last visit here was great.    Perfect weather over the Labor Day weekend led to a great afternoon trying their September style Oktoberfest that is brewed in Munich.  I loved it.  Nice seasonal balance of flavors, served in a huge been stein, you just can't go wrong there.  When I do come here I tend to try their seasonal selection first, there are many that are very good.    Sometimes this place can get crazy, and if you aren't into that kind of atmosphere I recommend coming in the afternoons.   I would probably never come here in the evening again, though I have heard they cracked down on their tolerance of bozo drunken idiots.  This is always good to hear.  Bottoms up!

5C_IOqg5jcTVY107lRhWZA.text: I like this place. On a summer day I like the patio and balcony overlooking the Monongahela with the breeze off the river.  I like the cold, sharp, crisp beers. I like the fun, live German bands inside. I even like the Disney-esque German uniforms the waitstaff wears.  What I don't like about this place is the food.  I love sauerkraut, with "sauer" being the key part of that word. The kraut here lacks the sauer.  The sausages are bland.  The chicken dishes are bland.  Even the beer cheese is pretty dang bland.    The two best things I've found?  The pretzels with mustard (just regular ol' yellow mustard), and the salads, which are big with just the right amount of crunchy iceberg and romaine mixed with just the right amount of flavorful green leaves from other lettuces.  I'm not saying they're the best salads around, but they're better than anything else on the menu.

ahg23r1t6899Bo0UBvB5gQ.text: It's a great place for a lot of college kids to come on Thursday night. But their food is OK. Their beer is good price with a lot of beer if you are a heavy drinker. Their beer cheese pretzel is decent.

XerE4UJzEJp5wiU4w5a1MA.text: We took our boss to Hofbrauhaus yesterday for lunch to celebrate her birthday at my suggestion, because we often have alumni events here and have always had a good time.  We had a group of eight and were seated on the deck since it was a gorgeous day.  We arrived and were seated by 12:15.  After waiting 10 minutes, a waitress appeared and asked if anyone wanted drinks.  I ordered a Diet Pepsi and my coworkers all stuck with water.  The waitress left and we waited.  And waited.  And waited.    At 12:40 when we still had not ordered, I went inside and flagged down a busboy, explaining that we were on a limited schedule and had not even gotten drinks yet.  He apologized, grabbed a waitress, and immediately came to take our order.  They said they had gotten crushed all the sudden and assured us our food would be out right away.  At 12:45 (half an our after we had arrived)  they finally brought my soda and said again our food was on the way.  At 1:05 when we still had not gotten any food or seen our server, I once again went inside and flagged down a bus boy, saying that we would need our food packed to go as we no longer had time to eat.  He promised it would be taken care of right away.  At 1:10 our waitress brought out a birthday sundae with a candle in it, which-- while incredibly thoughtful-- was not helpful since we still had not gotten out meals.  She said again our food would be out "soon" and I said again that we needed it to go.  We also asked for our checks.    At 1:15 we were finally given our checks (though we still had gotten any food) and discovered that the checks were incorrect.  We paid the incorrect checks anyway because by then we were starving and late.    At 1:20-- over an hour after we arrived-- we finally got our cold food to go.  This was a terrible and embarrassing birthday experience.  We ended up eating cold food in a meeting because of this.  There was no adjustment to our (incorrect) checks.  Despite working across the street from here, none of us will be back any time soon.

YUu90dj7dwDPNHLcLtDzDg.text: Went here a few times but this is my first review. Definately loud inside for a Tuesday. We ordered the pretzels and cheese, salmon, Pittsburgh steak salad and Wiener schnitzel. Everyone liked what they had; the portions were large; everything was hot; prices were a little high; and our waitress was pretty absent after the food was delivered. The service definitely could've been better. Overall it was a three star night.

DmQ6EEKA-ApirjsaWaQnug.text: If your looking for German food and entertainment there is no better place!  The menu is all German food, desserts and beer!  The place is HUGE! There is a beer hall and bar where people stand on their seats and sing while eating, there is a beautiful porch and below is an outdoor beer garden with lights, there is also a quiet beer hall.  There is a souvenir room and they have a rent your own stein so that you can come back and have a stein with your name ready for you to drink with!  I ordered the potato pancakes with sour cream and apple sauce, it was good! And I got a Bavarian cream puff!  The servers were all attentive even though they were packed!   A must see!

lg4L-6cEv-3IKBFu1yXTMg.text: My first real trip to the Hofbrauhaus house. it was for a friend's birthday. It was an Saturday night, but it was completely packed. we had to wait outside for about 35 minutes. There was plenty of outdoor seating, so it wasn't bad at all.  we finally got seated and it took a few minutes to get ordered but I expected that since it was packed. Every seat was taken. I had some wine because I'm really not much of a beer person.  The wine was super delicious.   The food was really good. I know had spinach dip. My boyfriend had schnitzel and he loved it.   The experience is where the 4 star comes in people dancing on tables and singing covers of songs. It's really fun and definitely worth the trip at least once.

Z4sHelQAXKWeUH-gVH2iLg.text: Better beer to be had.  Hofbrauhaus is still pretty new and I admit the noisy part of the place is a lot of fun.  I found the beers to be only so-so.  Get the pretzels with beer chesse.  They're really good.  This is the kind of place you go very infrequently with a large group.  One time I was there we were seated next to people who really were not into the vibe.  A real killjoy but a risk you take in a beer hall type of place.  Prices were reasonable.  Can be very crowded.

I0m_DSxPRZ_xEQQcpzAxqQ.text: I would call Hofbrauhaus the Applebee's of Beer Halls, but that's only because it's a chain. The food is actually quite good and the beer - though not so good as to make me tear up - is good. This place gets PACKED, though, so I suggest either getting there early or else heading down to the outside picnic tables. The scene there is much more relaxed and the view is great.  BEER SELECTION: Lagers all, with the occasional altbier. Solid, but not overly impressive. FOOD SELECTION: Traditional german stuff with an emphasis on sausages. Good and well priced. SERVICE: It gets noisey in the hall, what with the singing, yelling, cheering, and dancing, so you'll have to forgive the waitstaff if they always seem to be in a rush.  Shotskis are to be shared with four people. Jager and Honey Jager shots are poured into shot glasses glued to a ski, then drank at one time by the participants. Have fun!

vC5-6M4FkuicICo2tZgdXA.text: This review is only for the beer and experience. Hofbrauhaus is huge and fun if you are there with a big group. The beer is tasty, especially the lager and dunkel.  IMO the hefeweizen is a bit heavy with the banana and clove but perhaps that's how a True hefeweizen  should taste like.   I get annoyed inside with repetitions of living on a prayer, sweet caroline, sweet home alabama and steelers fight songs so I'm almost always outside. The people there eat it up but having already experiencing four years of drunk idiots singing journey, experiencing it again is nauseating.   The kids are young, Many 21 year olds chose this place to celebrate their coming of age. But really the clientel ranges from these 21 year olds to 80 year olds attempting to get jiggy with it.   Outside is very nice, ample seating and nice views.  Its a great pace to take visitors to see something they can't see everywhere.   Overall, a place to go with friends to enjoy a beer before heading somewhere else or a place to linger all night if that's your thang.    Like tanqueray, hofbrauhaus is good only in moderation.

exIvVlz1LGEQcjfMoDoSjA.text: Tried the beer sampler here and it was good. My wife had one of there pretzels and loved it. I am not a fan of pretzels myself though. Nice atmosphere with huge picnic like tables. I think it would depend on time of day and live band or not if you would want to bring your kids. We were there in the afternoon and it was quite.

TZFPOjSjkIypDlMkT5OD_A.text: After a little more than a week in Ireland with my husband, it was good to get out on a Friday night with the girl posse.  We decided on dinner and a movie and we wanted to try some place we hadn't been to before.  Hofbrauhaus tries to replicate the 400 year old Hofbrauhaus in Munich.  Now since I'm 1/2 German, I thought this place would really appeal to me.  For an appetizer, we started on the pretzels with beer cheese.  I think that they are freshly baked, but they certainly are so delicious.  My main course was the Wursteller, which was Mettwurst, Bierwurst, and Bratwurst.  Piled high with sauerkraut (I love 'kraut.  Why-oh-why do I love stinky foods?), and mashed potatoes, it was so good.  They reportedly have great burgers here too.  No visit to a good German joint would be complete without dessert.  So we split two orders of Appel Strudel with vanilla and raspberry sauce.  I shared one with my friend Marla.  Sherry and Maryann split the other.  Like I always say, "Pump that insulin, Susan, pump!"  One thing, this place can get very busy, so it's best to go early like we did.

NLNMl_txQRRkxdYgvDn0HA.text: Great beer (especially their Dunkel , a dark lager), good Oompah band for music, good service.  The sauerkraut and ham ball appetizers, the fried pickles, soft pretzels and potato pancakes were delicious.  The wait was 75 minutes so we didn't stay for dinner.  If you want camaraderie singing along to Sweet Caroline while drinking a good brew than this is the place for you.

Y0bTHoUoqkxQSdBub-q6ng.text: This review is just for my meal...nothing else. I admit I am not a fan of this place to go hang out.  Maybe if I was younger and lived close....but it's way to loud for me. I don't want to yell over the oompah band  the entire time I'm trying to hang with friends.  I'd find the music tolerable if I was drinking heavily. But people come here for the atmosphere knowing what they are getting into...so Im not going to rate this place based on my dislike for something that is at the heart of the business. So with all this being said...I had a good meal last week.  Had a gift certificate there and needed to wait out traffic. I got lucky coming in early in the evening because it wasn't the full band....considerably more quiet.  I ordered the Sauerbraten....really flavorful.  If you don't like traditional sauerkraut, this dish comes with red apple kraut.  Awesome.  My BF had the pork with crackling.  This dish is insane.  Wish I had taken a photo of it.  If you love pork and the fried pork skin....heaven.  For me it was a bit too much work to get the right amount of pork and the right amount of cracklin in each bite to make it nicely flavored. But if you have the time while drinking your huge liter of beer....then go for it.

W2JEqaW5M5_B1qWnLmPZLw.text: Ah German food, so simple in execution but yet the results are so pleasing.  For those that aren't familiar with German food, here's a crash course on what to expect:  generous helpings of meat, veggies, and beer.  The brand new Hofbrauhaus in Pittsburgh's Southside Works is no exception.    I've been here several times, both before and after traveling to the original Hofbrauhaus in Munich, Germany earlier this summer.  I'm happy to say that the experience here is as close as you can get to the "real" thing.  The beer hall is loud, you share your table with complete strangers, beer is served by the liter, and often times there is live German music (did I mention that dancing on the tables is encouraged?).  The food is very good and a great representation of the German style.  But what you'll really come here for is the beer.  Brewed on the premises under direction of the Reinheitsgebot (German Purity Law), they include a Lager, Light Lager, Dunkel, Weizen, and a seasonal brew.  At prices just under $8 per liter, it's a steal compared to other bars in the Southside.  Even if there a few Americanized touches here and there, it feels like an authentic German experience right in your back yard.  What more could you ask for?  Prost!

However, the HbH Pittsburgh gets high mark for having a wonderful beer garden patio, a heated terrace, and a private and quiet dining hall.

The whole of Pittsburgh doesn't have enough polka outfits to pay each to play one night of the week?   I had German friends complain at how ridiculous Hofbrauhaus in Munich was, but if they saw this, I think they'd want to shoot themselves.  Also, I found the original in Munich not so bad- decent prices, decent food, and mostly full of older german couples or men!  Maybe during Oktoberfest it's awful, but I liked it.   This was just pathetic- the "german dishes" were quite frankly terrible.  I forget which sausage my husband ordered, but he said it tasted just like breakfast links.  I ordered the kasespaetzle, a dish I ate a lot of and liked in Germany.  The two versions can't even be compared.  This one was full of nearly raw onions and tasted like it was covered in alfredo sauce, and was pretty much one big lump of doughy noodle.  The only reason it's getting 2 stars is because the beer was good (though not being a beer connoisseur I can't really compare to the original). vCFAppubqxItmf0J2BT7VQ.text: Hofbrauhaus' German-Beer Hall inspired restaurant/pub provides an alternative dining and drinking experience in Pittsburgh. The atmosphere at Hofbrauhaus makes the visiting this establishment worthwhile. There is an eclectic group of people all indulging in heavily encouraged drinking while listening to upbeat traditional folk music. There are also skis for drinking beer; if that means something to you then Hofbrauhaus has it; if that sounds like nonsense then go to Hofbrauhaus to see what I mean.  If you are willing to participate in the high energy cheering and singing, then you'll definitely enjoy an evening here.  When I came here we ordered a few samplers, pretzels, and bratwurst to share. I have no standard to compare the authenticity to, but the quality was surely acceptable.  As for beer, Hofbrauhaus brews its own beer on site. You can order a sample of the house beers and go from there. Also, I've read that Hofbrauhaus serves Cask Ales, but I cannot confirm this from memory.

8N9_5OM0UNoC62FfXyF29A.text: This place is a curious mix of really good and so-so...  The good... - I am looking forward to summer, because their outdoor space is fantastic.  Right on the river with a great view and some fun activities.   - If you are looking for a fun, rowdy vibe in a place that isn't dirty and completely nuts, this is the place.  It's a good drinking atmosphere.    The so so... - The food.   My companion grew up in Germany and wasn't impressed with any of it.   As an American, I thought half of what we ordered was really good.  Half was really not.   The winners were the pretzels with bier cheese, the potato pancakes, and the cob salad.   The pork shank with cracklins, the pierogies, sauerkraut, and cabbage were all not so great.    - The portions.   They must be trying to compete with their ridiculously over-portioned neighbor, the Cheesecake Factory, because every dish we ordered was humongous.  Not a lot of healthy options to begin with and the portions are over the top.   I recommend sharing for sure.    - The music.  They had an accordion player in all of the traditional garb.  He stopped at prescribed intervals to sing some German song and make a toast.  It was cute the first time, but quickly became repetitive.   Would probably have been fine if we were there for drinking and not dinner, but as it was, we were sort of over it.    A couple of other things to know.    - Valet service is $8 and the area where I had to pull it was pretty far from the front door.  When leaving, I had to walk out in the rain to get to the valet stand.  He told me I could wait inside and he'd come get me, but that was only after I asked.  Several people were standing out in the rain waiting for their cars. - If you are there to eat, request a table closer to the bar (and farther from the music).  We had to shout to be heard over the accordion.

Bs7F1yX09Nfy5AnA07TBLw.text: I still don't get the fascination with Hofbrauhaus. Working close by has led to countless happy hours there, and living close by has led to meeting friends there quite a bit...which means I've been there a lot, but rarely because it was my destination of choice.  First, the beer is good and plentiful. Heck, depending on the monthly brew, the beer is sometimes REALLY good, and the food is decent. I've never eaten an actual meal at Hofbrauhaus, but I've tried almost all of their apps since I'm typically there for happy hour, and they're all pretty good. Fried pickles, fried sauerkraut balls, soft pretzels with beer cheese...I mean, what's there to complain about? The perfect app menu for beer-accompaniment.  Unfortunately, Hofbrauhaus loses me with the atmosphere. I'm fully aware that it's the atmosphere that is supposed to be the draw, and based on the crowds they get, it's working. Perhaps I've outgrown the old get-drunk-then-stand-on-a-table-and-toast-in-a-language-that-I-don't-really-know stage of my life, but I often find the main room of Hofbrauhaus to be loud and obnoxious as opposed to celebratory. Granted, I prefer being able to hear the people I'm talking to, and I don't need a random Tuesday in the Spring to feel like Octoberfest, but based on the number of people that go to Hofbrauhaus, I'm clearly in the minority.  The safe bet for a good time at Hofbrauhaus for those of us looking for a more relaxed experience that takes advantage of the positives of Hofbrauhaus while skipping the annoying, is this: get a small group of friends and hit the outside beer garden when the weather is nice. There are few things more relaxing than partaking in a delicious liter of beer in the beer garden...next to the river...on a sunny day. If the weather isn't cooperating, another option is to get there early before the craziness starts in the evenings, but regardless of how happy the tunes from the accordion might sound, the drab environment just never does it for me.

VWNTlRcc4MYsd9qVGnF7ww.text: The Hofbrauhaus here in Pittsburgh is, in my opinion, the best one here in the states (we've been to all of them except Cincinnati). I'm even a vegetarian and have had plenty of options to choose from. Their veggie burger on a pretzel bun with beer cheese is delicious. The nachos without meat & the appetizer sampler (minus the sauerkraut balls) are also good meat-free options.   The atmosphere is so fun at the Hofbrauhaus. y6tuZya-ufZhqEZ9yidz9Q.text: Food was awesome. Ambience was like Oktoberfest. Large beer selection with a friendly, knowledgeable staff. hfcPGx3Y8yKL1yxXmzFyrw.text: This restaurant was amazing!  First, the prices were great.  We were a bit taken aback when the bill arrived, but approximately 12.00 for a lunch buffet was a great price and the drinks were fair too.  The food itself, for a buffet was excellent!  Very German and I would highly recommend the mashed potatoes and the sauerkraut!    Our waitress was prompt and attentive and kept a close check on us.  The entire atmosphere was very, very German, which lent to the entire experience!  As I said, we were there for lunch, so it wasn't crowded and I can't speak to the dinner time activities, but I would definitely eat here again!

yHQDbBg7iyWdjmIK2RV8KA.text: Although this is a chain restaurant, which my husband and I try to side step in favor of local spots, I can't say a bad word about the Hoffbrahaus. I'm a consistent fan of the "Radler" which is a customizable shandy, half hefeweizen and half lemonade mixed in house. You can also try a darker version with a dark brew and rootbeer.  I've sampled many of their offerings but I've found my niche with the sauerkraut balls as an appetizer (dip them in the honey mustard - wow!) and the comforting, creamy and delicious Rahm spatzle.  The atmosphere is always lovely and entertaining, great place to drink, eat and sing the night away!

O7M5jwnN6gr1gI2WJx2ytA.text: Great German beer, okay German food at reasonable prices in a humongous beer hall/restaurant/patio/bier garden. The lighting that they use reminds me of an amusement park and you can easily have a conversation. Been here many times and the service has always been great. My only knock on this place is the food. I love German food but I wish they would put in as much tender love-n-care into their food as they do their beer.

lokWGlIuM8NY24_ovWg7-g.text: Hofbrauhaus is not for me.  They have tasty sandwiches (pretzel sandwich!), pretzels and beer cheese, and--of course--beer. The Dunkel is the best of the regular options, to my taste.    I'm not into the whole concept-- the canned, Disney-version-of-Bavaria with Oompa accordion music, waitresses in skimpy outfits, drunk people standing on communal tables, kitschy sing-alongs, mega-sized TV screens with all the sports events blaring-- just no. The noise and the crowds mean that you need to go there for the express purpose of enjoying the aforementioned other stuff.  There's no doubt it's a fun place; it's just that Hofbrauhaus is not my idea of fun.   I feel a bit bad about writing a critical review without suggestions for improvement, as it's the whole corporate concept that's not to my taste.  The point of this review is to suggest that there are so many better options for grown ups to drink a beer in Pittsburgh, especially if conversation is a goal.  If watching sports, singing, and getting smashed are goals, then you might have a heck of a fun time.

cihLrlhGj3GgpGvA9yhQVA.text: I. Love. Hofbrahaus.   Some of the best German food around - I dont care if its from a world-wide chain - it is DELISH. The bier cheese is amazing, pretzels, schnitzels, potato salad, sausages, sour kraut and of course the beer selection. I love it all. Food is always hot and well seasoned and I have always had good service here - despite the obvious fact that this place can really get crowded and extremely busy. The only reason I am giving 4 of 5 stars is due to it being very overly loud at times if you happen to be there during evening hours (some people like to start the party early, even if you are not sitting in the party hall).

tCOORI9PvIkCN1jRYknzgA.text: Good beer. Good pretzels with bier cheese. Good environment. All in all, a good place for some German grub and drinks.   On the other hand, this place definitely attracts the rowdier crowd. With it's long, shared tables, raucous clientele, and live music on the weekends it's not an environment for the faint of heart.

hFpgtJRwrWV2b1x9222Wag.text: If you can't make it to Oktoberfest than the Hofbrauhaus will make you feel as if you are there or bring back memories. Das schnitzel war sehr gut und die hefe weizen war noch besser. The music was non-stop and everyone was having a great . The location is right on the river so you have a choice of sitting in either inside or outside. You can sit outside if you don't want to shout to have a conversation.   The food came quickly, but you can still enjoy some serious pretzels and cheese before your meal arrives. They don't close until 2am so there is plenty of time to pace yourself and enjoy the best beer the world has ever known. So whether a 1/2 liter or a full stein have a good time with some good food with family and friends.

1eqdbhw4Avh0LYxA0bEfhA.text: I was here for a business dinner, and the company was great, the beer was great, but the food was just...okay. Maybe I'm not a fan of German food?  We had a private area on the side, as there was a huge group, and the dinner was buffet. The place was dimly lighted, like most restaurants, but this comes into play later....Nothing was marked, so I didn't know what anything was, except for the big fat pretzels. Them I knew! But they weren't super warm and there wasn't any mustard or cheese to dip them into. But they were decent. There was also brisket, then breaded cutlets of chicken (I think)-is that schnitzel?, some chicken in a mushroom sauce and a few other things, although I don't remember them because I didn't eat them.  The chicken cutlet was good, but could have used some sauce or something. The chicken in the mushroom sauce was deelish, and the brisket...was not brisket. Okay, remember I said it was dark in there? And I may have had a couple beers or so, but I took a bite of the brisket and was like. Woah. Not brisket. Not brisket. I had to ask my friend and she said "Of course not, you silly Texan, it's pickled sauerkraut!" So yeah. Not at all brisket.  We had apple strudel for dessert and that was good stuff! But the meal was just okay. Again, it may have been just me and my tastes.  I should be back here next year for the business meeting, and if they have dinner here again, of course I'll go, but I definitely won't get the "brisket"!

KUXDDRYTF0pPGxueRt79NA.text: Hofbrauhaus was our first stop in Pittsburgh. It was highly recommended and they weren't wrong. The atmosphere was incredible. Since it's October there was a band. The tavern is celebrating October fest. Seating is communal so everyone is friendly and singing and drinking together. I had a liter or two or three of their own October Fest beer. It was very good. It had a crisp taste and a nutty finish. My wife had the lager. It was late when we arrived so we just ordered some appetizers. We shared the pretzels, cheese and bacon fries, and perogies. Everything was home made and delicious. Only down side is the line to be seated. I definitely recommend Hofbrauhaus for some awesome craft German beer, and a fun atmosphere. Btw all staff are wearing outfits from German taverns.

uIqcPfT30-mysonmA36qdw.text: I was here for work, staying right next door at the Hyatt, so on a wintery snowy evening it was the most convenient place to try. First strike against was a bit of chaos in the front, with hopeful diners started to pile up with no greeters. However, once we were seated, the fun began. We had live entertainment with an accordionist deluged with announcing birthday after birthday throughout the evening...apparently this is a popular birthday spot! Nice big place that managed to feel cozy at the same time.  Second strike was by not even 7pm, their most popular pork dish was already sold out! So I had the ribeye instead. It came out medium well instead of medium rare as I ordered it, but it didn't stop me from devouring it. It was delicious as was the food in general (we had the soft pretzel appetizer that hit the spot, too).  I haven't been to a real German Oktoberfest, but with the outfits the servers (all female, it seemed) wore, it was kinda like a Teutonic Hooters!

YbBC5ACmcZZpK_lzp7-7SA.text: This place is awesome if you're looking for good German food. The beer is very good as well. tspKcLddj1jSd-hPXNhavg.text: 3.5 experience. First dinner in Pittsburgh! Also, my first time trying German food!   Party of 4, reservation at 7 pm. TBH, it was pretty empty when we came...but I hear it gets hella packed later at night and on weekends!   Parking: street or parking structure a block away. The area is still under renovation, so please pardon the dust.   Menu: extensive and the font is hard to read (LOL). Separated into:  appetizers, soups, salads, side dishes, burgers & sandwiches, HB specialties, Wurstl, Schnitzel, and Haus favorite.   TLDR;  Service: 4/5- Ladies were super nice and gave us ample time to order. But, they did forget us halfway through the meal...  Ambiance: 4/5- indoor has a country band playing on stage, and a really nice bar with huge beer tanks. Outdoor seating that overlooks the river. They even have games on the bottom floor! The area is a new shopping center, so you should walk around after your meal if it isn't too dark or chilly! There is also a running trail behind the restaurant.   Quality of food: 3/5- maybe this isn't my type of food, but for what it's worth, I would only categorize this as "American traditional".   Pricing: 3.5/5- pretty reasonable for the quantity you get! Alcohol is also decently priced.   We finally ordered:   SOUPS 1. 2 Kartoffelsuppe (creamy potato soup) // YUM! Isn't this just like clam chowder without the clams? 2. 1 gulaschuppe (beef stew with tomato/paprika base) // YUM! Maybe because I was on the plane all day, but this settled my tummy.  SPECIALTIES 1. Scheweinebraten (slow cooked pork roast) // Oh wow, big portion! I actually really like the pork. Kind of reminds me of pork loin though? Potato dumpling was not bad...why are people obsessed with this?  2. Sauerbraten (marinated beef) // Oh boy...too much red wine sauce. The beef was also too dry...but the sides were good!  3. Dunkel bourbon salmon (pan seared Atlantic salmon fillet) // Yum! Fresh. Also came with some steamed vegetables.   WURSTL 1. Wurstplate (bierwurst, bratwurst, frankfurter) // I'm not into sausages...my friend ordered this and finished it clean though!  HAUS FAVORITE 1. Half rack of baby back ribs // YUMMM. I haven't had good ribs in forever!!! I like. Better than other places I've had in CA!   Overall, interesting dining experience. I wouldn't mind coming here for some big portion, comfort food! However, quality does sacrifice. Everything is hella rich in flavor...maybe too much.

baKgDMrhb8Gyh4-RdLoMVg.text: I'm not sure why I haven't reviewed this place yet but let me share my qualifications:  1) I grew up in Germany 2) I used to have German citizenship 3) I speak German fluently and visit relatives often  4) My German family is from southern Germany 5) I've been to Munich and the Hofbrauhaus more than once   Despite all the above I give Hofbrauhaus 4 stars, and here's why:  THE BEER. The beer is actually legit! It tastes 100% like a True southern German Hefeweizen should taste. How they did it I don't know. I will confess that given the vast number of breweries in Germany I was never a regular drinker of Hofbrau. So it's possible that there may be subtle differences here vs there. I mean the water alone could cause that. HOWEVER, it's better by far than *any* imported keg of German Hefeweizen, I don't care if it's Weihenstephan or Paulaner or Franziskaner or whatever. You get my drift. The beer here is 100%  Forget the food. It's fine. Some of it is legit (regular schnitzel, regular Spatzle, red kraut) most of it is not (cheese spatzle, in particular). But whatever, the beer is legit. And the outside space is great in the summer including the real German tables and benches (the long skinny ones).   Also the service typically is pretty lame, but again, whatever. That's actually fairly accurate to Germany as well XD  Anyway, that is all. I probably have a dozen pictures of a Hefeweizen Halbe (the tall skinny glasses) in my photo album over the years because I pretty much text a photo of it to my family every time is go there for one in the summer but you all know what that looks like and if not there's plenty on Yelp already!  So cheers!

vplkRMuyeJo-7If2sEUkHw.text: Decor is 10/10 and so is the beer but the food is garbage. I thought they were going to sell legit Bavarian food because some of it is imported. They managed to even Americanize the pretzel. The giant pretzel was nothing like a Bavarian pretzel- it was a glorified philly pretzel. I am not a pretzel elitist but they don't got the food down. A Bavarian pretzel is dark brown, borderline black, matte, and a lot denser. This was soft and fluffy and the cheese sauce was pretty much a less tangy cheese whiz.   The warm potato salad was garbage - slices were undercooked and seasoned all wrong. The use of food service thin sliced American bacon in the fried cabbage did the dish no favors because it comes off as pre-rendered so the fat didn't lend itself to the dish, instead you had these sad, floppy slices of bacon to suggest the miserable life the pig had. I know you have to adapt to the resources around you but it detracted from the dish. Cabbage was completely unremarkable.   The ultimate abomination was the schnitzel itself. The texture was spongy. It was disconcerting to why a cutlet had that texture. And it was not remotely crunchy for something deep fried which made it even worse. This my friend, is not a schnitzel. The wine mushroom sauce for the jaegerschnitzel was not rich and meaty like a real German gravy but was thin and flavorless like something out of a package.   This food was essentially mediocre theme park (a la Dixieland) "German" food and I'm confused why was it so mediocre when German food is probably the safest "ethnic" food and arguably has the most influence on American food overall (hot dogs, burgers).   For the love of Gott, HB Pittsburgh, make authentic and GOOD Bavarian food for the prices you charge or lower them if you're going to cut corners.   Silver lining is that the beer is solid and served at the right temperature. You wouldn't be able to tell the difference between this pint and one you got in a Biergarten in Munich.

gKlqZKMPH-fhsMFyc0hAWQ.text: A little bit of context: This happened late April. I understand this review is relatively late, but my girlfriend and I were just recapping this unfortunate incident and felt that it would better to speak about it late rather than never.  A little more context: I had visited Hofbrauhaus multiple times and was almost a regular there every Thursday. I had enjoyed their service and food almost every time previously.  So 3 Indian guys, one Hispanic guy and one Caucasian girl walk into a bar. We're asked for IDs. Now for those who are unaware, non-US citizens working full time jobs in the states have a US government issued ID called an Employment Authorization Document(EAD) card. This is an accepted form of identification and I have used it to fly and to apply for credit cards, etc. The manager was adamant that we needed a US state ID/Driver's license or a passport to enter the premises. We told him that we don't have American Driver's licenses, but we were able to each present three alternative forms of identification (EAD cards, international driver's licenses & an expired PA state ID) but this really didn't help our case. We were understanding that every organization has it's rules and we were actually impressed that the organization decided to stay True to it's principles. Also, we're all 26 year olds (so we've been 21 for a while, but again, that really shouldn't make a difference). This is when things got a little sketchy. A group of all Caucasian students entered behind us. Now, I agree, some people look a lot younger than they actually are, but it sometimes is easy to identify when a person is more likely to be 18 and not 21. I still will admit that everyone in the group could have been 21 and this is just me being cynical after being turned away from a bar. However, the same manager who refused us entry, barely glanced at their IDs. I'm no expert but it would be stupid to let a group that looks so young to be let in without a slightly more careful examination. This was more ironic as the manager had previously lectured us about the integrity of the institution. And finally when we were leaving, he asked my Caucasian girlfriend where she was from? This is just a rant but I think it's a little inappropriate to where my obviously white girlfriend is from and again, I'm no expert but his tone indicated some curiosity that as to why a white girl was spending time with a group that consisted of men of color. Either way, it's also a little ridiculous to make conversation with the only female of a group whom you've just kicked out. You asked us to leave and we were. Don't start asking questions that are none of your business.

a9z5HaAx42fI-SRtYDrAGA.text: I'm a beer loving girl.  Ever since I was a child I would steal a sip of my dad's frosty mug when he wasn't looking.  Now that I'm an adult and of legal drinking age, visiting Hofbrauhaus Pittsburgh I'm allowed to have a liter of beer,  or as I call it "beer as big as your face,  without the lecture.   With an accordion player dressed in lederhosen and women with corsets pushing up their assets, you feel like you've been transported on a European vacation.  German comfort food is on the menu with a little American flair. It's a destination spot - obviously I bring my Dad every time he visits Pittsburgh to make up for all of those stolen beers over the years.  Typically the only food I order are Bavarian pretzels and bier cheese.  The food isn't the best, but the beer makes me nostalgic.    If you're looking to get the full experience,  stop by on the first Wednesday of the month - its keg tapping day!  New beer is unveiled,  a parade of men and women playing instruments and waving flags while bringing out the first new keg of the month.  If you arrive early enough (say 6pm) you can get a table and stand in line for a free first taste of the beer.  That tower of mugs will be filled with a frothy brew and I'll have a big smile on my face.  If you're looking for something off the beaten path and feel a bit parched,  fill your mug up with some bier at Hofbrauhaus.  PROST!

5DB56iQ5dWz-fBeSrF7NAQ.text: OK was here on business and we walked in from the street and sat down at a table. It was a Monday night so not busy at all.. Inside is the old German arrangement of the large wooden tables and benches, very heavy, hard to move and seat about 4-6 on each side.  It is also a loud place due to acoustics I think......Also with the table/bench arrangement, If someone wants to get up and in the middle of the bench 2 or 3 people will have to move. There is a huge seating area in a lower level also with benches and tables that I am sure is crowded on weekends with good weather and Oktoberfest. They serve beer by the liter or half liter just as in Germany, and the quality of the beer seemed to be the same as what you find in Germany. O8KWSY-TCzDcYfSZrtqRUQ.text: I know that this place is not "authentic," but I really don't care. As a Florida native, I grew up with chain restaurants and an occasional local Mexican place. German food was not just scarce, but nearly impossible to find in The Sunshine State.  I had been to two other German restaurants in Georgia and North Carolina before trying Hofbrauhaus right after we moved to Pittsburgh a couple years ago. The restaurants were in cliche "German" house-style locations and featured mediocre food only enjoyed by True German food lovers. At the Atlanta location, I turned up my nose to most of the food and remember nibbling on a cold pretzel for most of the evening.  Hofbrauhaus could not be any more different! It has four wonderfully unique sections of the restaurant - formal dining, bier hall, patio, and bier garden. I enjoy the bier hall earlier in the evening before it transforms into a bar, and the patio for late nights and spring/fall weather. Plus, it's covered, so we've even dined out there when it was raining.  The beer is great. My personal favorite is the Hefe Weizen - a delicious wheat beer with a light banana flavor. I also enjoy the Dunkel, their dark lager that hits the spot when the weather is cooler. Each month, they have a different monthly beer, and I look forward to Oktoberfest all year. Make sure to order it early in the month of September in case they run out!  I highly recommend The Works Sampler - pretzels, fried pickles, potato pancakes, and sauerkraut balls, all served with a complementary dip. It's a great appetizer to share with a group of four. Most of the entrees are between $10-15, which I think is very fair for the location and quantity of food. If ordering an appetizer, I would split an entree or sandwich with someone. My husband and I often split the Reuben or Schnitzel Sandwich, which are only $10 and plenty big enough for the two of us. Finally, though you probably won't have room, the Apfel Streudel is fantastic and definitely worth stretching your stomach just a little bit more for.  I would question myself if I was truly in the minority regarding my opinion of this restaurant... but all of our Southern friends and family adore this place. Everyone who comes back for a second visit has requested - even almost begged - to come back here. Several friends and family members have even returned to Florida in search of a similar German place and have been unsuccessful. Maybe it's because we don't have "refined" German palates, but I don't care... This restaurant has made several of us (including myself) who thought we hated German food now become a huge fan. And any restaurant that changes my mind about an entire genre is a gem in my opinion.

GOIjrL4MWdBLpBlZh5WsQg.text: Pretzels and bier cheese. Do it even if you don't think you want them. Amazing. I love the schnitzel sandwich and their spaetzle. The food here is delicious, probably the best German in the city. But we all know that everyone comes for the beer. Hefeweizen is my go-to. Live German music and you can stand on the tables to sing a little Sweet Caroline. And an outdoor biergarten. Definitely a great time and perfect for my large group of drunk, rowdy friends.   The location makes it difficult to reach if you're bar hopping the rest of Southside (without driving and parking in one of the Works' garages). And it was way more fun here when shot skis, a legit Oktoberfest and less intense bouncers were a thing. 2010 Hofbrau would have gotten 5 stars.

You need to be in the mood to be elbows to elbows, standing on tables, singing, screaming and doing shot skis as a group. The food is good as well. Very German. But I recommend going here for a fun night out with the guys or gals.

aimoc_MfXB4okvmc9vBR2g.text: A German beer garden is a German beer garden, huh?  Not if Monday is trivia night.  How fun!   Pierogies were eh, but sausage plate was good.  My date enjoyed beer in thick chilled glass.  Strudel with French vanilla ice cream hit the spot.  The beer hall has authentic German look and bar is very attractive.  Recommend.

--bGDU42tITaQnOfRcUltA.text: Look, you don't have to be a historian to understand the evils that Germany has been responsible for (and therefore I don't need to explain here). But there is an evil that has somehow eluded the iron shackles of shame....the evils of German food.  It is easily in the bottom 3 of ethnic cuisines.  So I guess that makes my review a bit biased.  But let me regale you with some truth, dear reader; WHOM AMONGST YOUR FRIENDS IS A GERMAN FOOD FAN?!!?! What's that I hear?  Crickets?  That's what I thought.  And I am not counting anyone who has friends named Hans or Helmut or Kurt etc...Beer cheese? Let the Italians and French handle cheese, let the Germans handle beer and roads without speed limits.  (Kraftwerk is my favorite German export, check them out sometime).  Potato pancakes are bland and unappealing.  The thing with pancakes is this....they're not good for you, even these starchy messes.  So if you're going to indulge, go whole hog and go to a breakfast place that specializes in them. (Don't you love how pancakes have escaped the wrath of dietitians and the public? It is a desert that has hitched its ride to breakfast.  What a scam, no wonder most of us get sweaty and out of breath just reading yelp reviews). German sausages!?!?! GO TO CURE AND GET GOOD PORK PRODUCTS.  THE GERMANS CAN'T DO PORK EITHER!!!    I guess Hofbrahaus was fighting with one hand behind their back in the first place.  Anyways...this is a fair to middling drinking place.  If you have out of town friends who come from a relatively rural or small town..they might enjoy the gimmick.     The beer garden itself is a pretty nice spot to enjoy beers on the weekend as well...so I have to acknowledge that.  But it is quite Bro heavy...so if that's not your scene, I get it.    IF THIS RESTAURANT WERE A MUSICIAN/BAND: Frankie Yankovic.  Polka is pretty bad by most measures, but old people and drunks  love it.  But they can't defend their love of it.

d7-SLkvn5w5xNNRX9xmLjw.text: Always have to stop by HB house when I am in the area! I love this place! Great beer selection, awesome outdoor seating, and GREAT FOOD!   My man and I usually share an appetizer and an entree as they have very generous portions. This time around, we ordered the sampler appetizer platter and the sausage sampler plate. Of the items on the sampler appetizer platter, I only really liked the potato pancake and the pretzel with the bier cheese dipping sauce! Be warned, all the appetizers are pretty much deep fried so it was too much friedness for me lol. The sampler came with - 2 pretezels, 2 potato pancakes, 4 deep fried pickle spears, and 4 deep fried sauerkraut balls. It's definitely good to share with 3 or more people.  I enjoyed the sausage sampler entree plate. All the sausages were delish and came with plenty of mashed potatoes and sauerkraut. Yum!  Great place to get your eat and drink on!

o4XyOMRb0kxozLzAoYXLLw.text: Carbs aplenty...with a side of meat!  Tasty German food, but my favorite thing are the pretzels with the cheese sauce....love them!  This place has a few different dining atmospheres. There is the big hall, with long tables and communal benches where I have seen people dancing on the tables and singing along with the musician. There is also a more traditional dining room area. Then, there is an outdoor beer garden, which is pretty great when the weather is nice- umbrellas, a river view, and tables for both smaller and bigger groups, so it's a great place to bring a crowd. No worries about having 'everyone in your party present in order to be seated.' They are totally cool with people coming and going. The service is good. Even out in the beer garden, servers come by to check on you frequently, which is good if people keep coming and going from your big group....or if people decide they are hungry at different times.   Now, the beer....I'm more of a cocktail girl, but everyone here seems to enjoy the beer choices...and the sizes. They offer beers in the liter and half-liter size. There is something enjoyable about hefting a weighty 1L glass....this beer is no joke, though. Once, while passing through the indoor hall, someone vomited right in front of me. So, watch out for those liter beers. They pack a punch, and not everyone handles it well. One final note - the outfits the waitresses wear make me feel like a bad feminist for patronizing this place, but I do it anyway.

E-iBlZ0haL9gpw6eSIQ2pw.text: Great beer and great food! I've been to the original in Munich and this is nearly as good an experience. On a Saturday night, it fills up quickly with standing room only, so show up early and stay all night. Once the band gets going, people start dancing on the tables and having a great time.

J0tZ04o8r6I01_VG2dDbKw.text: Their beer was decent but overall I feel like there are better breweries and beer destinations in the city. I do enjoy stopping in occasionally for the atmosphere. The German music, great hall setup, shot-skis and lederhosen can make for a rowdy crowd at times.

yAZD39KeK2gFpkVT9CHaCA.text: This is one of my favorite places in the Pittsburgh area I've been here numerous times.  The draft beer is always good but don't except a ton of choices to be on tap all at once.  Don't listen to the negative reviews by the annoying foodies and hipsters.  I mean seriously are they ever happy?  They build a place in Pittsburgh that does not revolve around sports and TV's yet they still complain.  The menu has all sorts of things on it and I love the German potato salad and the red apple kraut.   The place can get really busy and loud though so if you're the type of person that is turned off by that I recommend trying to go when it is more low key.  In the warmer months there is outdoor seating that is used but in the colder months everyone is inside.

1WyEnh1B8ai6MMEPwgzhvA.text: Deafeningly loud with an insanely long wait, the Hofbrauhaus is a victim of its own success.  I really enjoyed the food (I had the spaetzel entree, and shared the sampler appetizers with our table -- the sauerkraut balls were a surprise for someone who doesn't even like sauerkraut!) and the beer (custom brewed), but can't imagine going back until the shine's off the apple and Pittsburghers have moved on to the next big thing.    Great spot to do heavy drinking, though -- the "shot-ski" was a popular choice at the tables around us, and every time one came out, it commanded the attention of the whole hall.

4ITprPrwE50jJUj32vmZSQ.text: Fun!  Great energy!    Its all about the beer people.....don't go looking for healthy food.  But you will find a good time and good beer....and its LOUD and jolly, so be prepared!  I was dining with Mom, so we opted for seating in the private dining room.  Big wooden tables, lots of great natural light from big windows.  We were offered seating on the patio too, which would have been really nice too.  We checked out the big hall when we were leaving and saw that there was live music and the entire room was alive and buzzing.  Looks like it would be great fun for a large group for a great night of drinking!

oEc4sTNtAMowxxyFjKLEEw.text: Hafbrauhaus is a lovely large brewery that sits on the river near the southside works.  They have a huge, and I mean huge beer hall that is very similar to the one in Munich.  The outdoor seating is awesome, and definitely my favorite part of the restaurant.  I'm not a beer far, and to be honest I go here often because DH is a beer connoisseur.  However I do love the beer here, and I don't feel bad that I can't sip down a nice glass of Merlot.  The food is just OK in my opinion, but then again I don't love eating large plates of sausage and meats.  The atmosphere is what redeems this place in my eye and it's awesome.  They always have live music and livelier people.  It's totally kosher to get smashed, dance on the tables, and belt your lungs out like a complete idiot...which I love.  Definitely check out this place for a good time.

2S_u9ZSrTKayjnRY9onB2g.text: this place rates a bit high on the bro-meter for my liking, but it can be fun with the right group of friends.  3 stars for doing a SHOT-SKI with my friend's mom.

49U_hONAwjQ_7amhMtJQIQ.text: love it here! you must come atleast once! for people of all ages and they do great jobs for birthdays! food is good and beer is great! they have a nice view of the river with outdoor seating, come early if you dont have a reservation-- they are always packed!

Q4EjAXg0x6pEJZQ8TaKIaw.text: Love this place. Great service. Great food (try the apple strudel) and the beer is excellent!  I try to bring everyone I know here now just so I have an excuse to come.  A real German beer garden experience.

kRkFD75ZgOtBk3iTJq-18Q.text: There's definitely a solid beer selection here, and the food's not bad either. However, the atmosphere was a little bit off to me. Even though there's an obvious German beer hall layout and polka band, there was a tangible southern twang (random southern songs, for example) that seemed really out of place at the locale.

zV3Xio8r6syhFYxNywEqyQ.text: Great place to go with a big group for something different than just heading out to the bars. I've been to the original one in Munich, and its American incarnation was pretty much along the same lines--beer, table-dancing (well, bench-dancing) to cheesy songs that everyone knows the words to, and lots of fun.  As far as beer goes, I wasn't big on their Weizen (wheat beer) and I'm not a fan of lagers in general. Love their Dunkel though, so I always order that. Most of my friends always get the light beer...no comment. Food here isn't very good. Zucchini planks are the only thing I like (huge portion, good for snacking with a group). All the meat dishes are extremely dry and heavy on the salt. Personally, I wouldn't recommend this as a dinner/drinking combo. Eat elsewhere, then come here to drink.  Another negative, the place gets way too crowded. If you come before 10pm, there will be an obscene wait for a table (and it's not fun if you don't get a table). Sometimes table reservations will be booked for the night as early as 7pm. Come late, and you can usually find some friendly strangers to jump in with. It's a little bit of a hassle to come here on a regular basis, but for birthdays or other special occassions, it's a great spot.

q0KahQPVaNgzUmp8LZx64Q.text: I have been to the orginal Hofbrauhaus in Muchen, Germany twice and this Pittsburgh replica is dead on considering it's age. The beer is the same formula as Germany however it IS brewed on the premises. You cannot go wrong with German food. The beer is excellent as well. I would recommend this to anyone on the mood for good food and good beer!

fV1RJsASHF3xvYWCO1Dj2Q.text: Food is good but not an amazing selection.  Inside is very noisy, making conversation difficult, but the outdoor seating overlooking the river is spectacular.

tFovaKCBcKvBZD9p_SntGA.text: Heavy rain did not deter people from celebrating Oktoberfest at Hofbrau in October 2009 as we ended up waiting on the line for a quoted time of 45 minutes before we can get seated in the beer hall at 6pm on a Saturday night. We were hungry and we were thirsty so we tried to make our way to the bar while we waited. Although the bar was fairly large, It was so packed we had to try and cut our way through 3 rows of people before we could even make it to the counter. We decided against it and pestered the hostess again if there was any available seating anywhere. It was also just another excuse to talk to the beautiful ladies welcoming people at the door.  They were immediately able to accommodate us at the separately enclosed quiet room and we took it. That service receives a check mark in my book for now.  There was of course a good selection of beer on the menu priced decently for light and dark beer connoisseurs alike. As for the food, I could've done better with my $14 then get the Weiner schnitzel here which ended up just being a fried pork cutlet with some sides. It tasted just like any standard fried pork cutlet and could be gotten for just $6 at Rose Tea Cafe in Squirrel Hill. I even ordered it with an egg on top (extra $1 charge with meal) and they forgot to put it on. So they decided to charge me $3 for one cooked egg to put on top of my pork cutlet by myself. (I rectified the situation when the bill came) Although the food was pretty standard and nothing to write home about or in this case, to yelp, one nice thing I liked about my meal was the German potato salad side. Of all the sides my friends and I ordered, we believed that that was the best side.  I'm sure the meal would've tasted a lot better if I had a couple more beers in me and we were swigging away in the beer hall but since we ate this sober, I was able to give my taste buds a full chance to try out Hofbrau's quality and a 3 out of 5 star rating of its food.   If I were to come back next time, we would probably just be in the bier hall for its beer at night. We weren't able to experience it, but it looked like everyone was having fun in there.

je72Iko7yBatD_f6QtMhjA.text: A great atmosphere for a drink and German food. If you're visiting the Pittsburgh area you should check it out.

-4Sjt0_DY4t4sr4ZtIPyEw.text: Somehow today was my first time at this Hofbrauhaus. I've been to the Munich and Sydney locations and they have done a good job in Steel Town.  Can't believe how busy it was on a Saturday at 3:00.  There are multiple locations to pull up a chair. There is a smaller room with maybe 20 tables closest to the street, which is the quietest place. The main hall easily has 50 tables and there is an outside deck with maybe another 30 tables. It appears there is another level below the deck but I'm not sure what that is used for.   Service was alright, generally fast but it seems some employees chose clothing maybe a size or two too small. Selection of beer is somewhat disappointing. Four standards and one seasonal that rotates monthly. Really? I've been to much smaller places that can put out better selection than this...   Food was alright, standard fare of Spaetzle, Pretzels, Schnitzel and Burgers. Appetizers are ridiculously priced at $10, but entrees range from $10-20 and seem more reasonable. Sandwiches and burgers are $7-9 and probably the best deal.   My favorite part was observing the German touches. If you have lived in Germany for any time, you will notice things like the picnic tables and silverware/napkins in a stein on the table that are distinctively German.

RGyBXwDk2wwOZ59e437qiQ.text: I was really excited to try this place since I love German food and drink. Okay, they serve beer by the liter, that is awesome! They have a full German menu, also awesome! The reason for three stars is that the service was pretty much "meh." I think our waitress quit judging by the reaction of our second waitress. The food was alright, nothing amazing, but acceptable nonetheless. I am not sure if it was an off night or if I built it up in my mind to be something it wasn't. Either way, it was an experience, but once was enough.

T0DH5fxm91Yn-TD4lzLXjg.text: Run far away. Then run some more. We celebrated a friend's birthday here, and the entire thing was actually new to my experience: the dance hall, the three-tiered outside seating area, the hoochies, the brosephs, the smoking, the fighting, how we got stared at for being gay. Won't be back. I actually have adopted use of 'Hofbrauhaus' as an adjective to mean 'way out of control and unpleasant' -- as in, "Oh, the law school halloween party was completely Hofbrauhaus."

eA2CPMyElaV6LoHzm55N8w.text: This is one of my favorite places to hit with the guys when I'm in the PGH. The brew is not half bad and the food keeps me satisfied. My only complaint is that this place can get really busy on the weekends and you have to pay for parking in a nearby garage.
